{{talk archive}} ==+Administrator== I would like to apply for admin-ship of Wiki Junior. What shall I do? Thanks, --[[User:Achlochan]] :These tools are not something that the community hands out to just anyone who asks. Rather, the tools are granted to those who have operated here for a while and have demonstrated that the community can invest trust in them. You have made two edits here, both of which were to make this request. Clearly we have nothing upon which to base such trust. If you wish to serve as an administrator here, you need to participate as an editor first. It will take time for that trust to be established. --[[User:Jomegat|Jomegat]] ([[User talk:Jomegat|talk]]) 13:53, 11 January 2011 (UTC) :[[Image:X mark.svg|15px| ]] '''Not done'''. Jomegat sums it up and I have a hard time considering this as a legitimate request. – [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] [[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] 15:13, 11 January 2011 (UTC) :Please also note that you cannot be an administrator of Wikijunior (not Wiki Junior) alone. One can only be the admin of the entire Wikibooks. [[::User:Kayau|Kayau]] {{toolbar|separator=dot |[[::User talk:Kayau|talk]] |[[::Special:Emailuser/Kayau|email]] |[[::Special:Contributions/Kayau|contribs]] |[{{fullurl::Special:Log|user={{urlencode:Kayau}}}} logs] |[http://toolserver.org/~soxred93/pcount/index.php?name{{=}}{{urlencode:Kayau}}&lang{{=}}en&wiki{{=}}wikibooks count] }} 06:48, 12 January 2011 (UTC)

{{talk archive}} ==+Uploader== I would like to request permission to upload a book: Real Estate Financing and Investment. This book is licensed under the Creative Commons and GNU at its original location here: http://worldacademyonline.com/book/real_estate_financing_and_investing/. I have also uploaded this to the Wiki Commons here: http://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Real_Estate_Financing_and_Investment.tif&page=2 Please let me know how I can make this book available on Wikibooks. Thanks, --[[User:SarahPats]] : You don't need to upload the tif version again, as the Wikimedia Commons file is accessible directly from here. What does need to be done is the tif version needs to be converted into wiki text form to allow anyone to easily edit it and maintain it. --[[User:Darklama|dark]][[User_talk:Darklama|lama]] 11:47, 10 January 2011 (UTC) :::Thanks for the information. That's good to know. I am sorry if this question is quite basic, but how do I edit the tif file as a wiki text? Thanks, --[[User:SarahPats]] ::::You (or someone) will need to run the TIF file through a TIF to text (usually PDF) piece of software. Otherwise known as an OCR (optical character recognition) tool. Once that's been done, the text will need to be copied across... I may have a chance to look at doing this during the week. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 11:59, 10 January 2011 (UTC) ::::Thanks for the information. I have googled how to do this and, while it sounds difficult, I will have a go at it! We'll see how long this takes me though! Thanks, --[[User:SarahPats]] :::::I have converted it into a PDF (well, 85 of them actually, one for each page). Just need to upload it all. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 13:25, 10 January 2011 (UTC) :::::That was very very fast. I havent even gotten to downloading the software for this and youre all done! ok, well thank you very very much for the help. Let me know if there is anything else that I need to do to get this book shared on Wikibooks! Thank you! --[[User:SarahPats]] ::::::As QuiteUnusual mentioned, what he has done resulted in PDFs of images... which means that what is needed is OCR, Optical Character Recognition. What I can do is take either the TIFFs or QU's PDFs, and run them through some OCR software I work with at my day job. OCR is only 95-99% accurate, so it will need a lot of correction, but I can put the stuff here if you want -- you will need to edit it to make it make sense. Let me see what I can come up with... [[User:Chazz|Chazz]] ([[User talk:Chazz|talk]]) 06:51, 25 January 2011 (UTC) ::::::Actually, it looks to be simpler to copy it from the original source. [[User:Chazz|Chazz]] ([[User talk:Chazz|talk]]) 17:59, 25 January 2011 (UTC)

== Customer focus (alpha = 0.72) == === Description ===
Through a detailed analysis of the literature, twelve constructs of integrated quality management strategies were identified: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Top management commitment|top management commitment]], customer focus, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier quality management|supplier quality management]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Design quality management|design quality management]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Benchmarking|benchmarking]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Statistical process control usage|SPC usage]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Internal quality information usage|internal quality information usage]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee empowerment|employee empowerment]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee involvement|employee involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee training|employee training]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Product quality|product quality]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier performance|supplier performance]]. Using a survey of 371 manufacturing firms, the constructs were then empirically tested and validated. For this purpose a confirmatory factor analysis approach was used.
=== Items ===
*Manufacturing managers are aware of the results of customer satisfaction surveys. *A summary of customer complaints is given to manufacturing managers regularly. *To achieve greater customer satisfaction, our company actively seeks ways to improve our primary product. *Our company has been customer focused for the past two years.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1540-5915.1996.tb00842.x Ahire et al. (1996): Development and Validation of TQM Implementation Constructs. Decision Sciences, Vol. 27, No. 1, pp. 23-56.]
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer involvement|Customer involvement]]
== Customer focus (alpha = 0.86) == === Description ===
The authors identify key constructs related to supply chain management. Based on a systematic instrument develop process, they develop a set of reliable, valid, and unidimensional measurement scales.
=== Items ===
*We anticipate and respond to customers’ evolving needs and wants. (0.57) *We emphasize the evaluation of formal and informal customer complaints. (0.75) *We follow up with customers for quality/service feedback. (0.76) *We interact with customers to set reliability, responsiveness, and other standards. (0.78) *Satisfying customer needs is the central purpose of our business. (0.67) *Customer focus is reflected in our business planning. (0.74)
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2003.12.007 Chen/Paulraj (2004): Towards a theory of supply chain management: the constructs and measurements. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 22, No. 2, pp. 119–150]
== Customer focus (alpha = 0.86; composite reliability = 0.84) == === Description ===
Eight quality management practices were identiﬁed by the authors: customer focus, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee relations|employee relations]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Management leadership|management leadership]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Process management|process management]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Product or service design|product/service design]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Quality data and reporting|quality data and reporting]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier quality management|supplier quality management]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Training|training]].
=== Items ===
*Extent to which customers are involved in product or service design. (0.58) *Extent to which customer satisfaction surveys are used in determining/identifying customers’ requirements. (0.62) *Extent to which managers are aware of the results of customer satisfaction surveys. (0.67) *Extent to which managers have access to a summary of customer complaints. (0.66) *Extent to which the organization actively seeks ways to improve the primary product/service in order to achieve greater satisfaction. (0.84) *Degree of employees’ understanding of who their customers are. (0.72)
Item 1 was adopted from Powell (1995); item 2 was created based on literature review; items 3–5 were adopted from Ahire et al. (1996); item 6 was adopted from Morrow (1997).
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.06.002 Kaynak/Hartley (2008): A replication and extension of quality management into the supply chain. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 26, No. 4, pp. 468–489.]
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer interaction|Customer interaction]]
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Created page with '== Employee relations (alpha = 0.91; composite reliability = 0.90) == === Description === Eight quality management practices were identiﬁed by the authors: [[Handbook of Manag...'
revision.text:
== Employee relations (alpha = 0.91; composite reliability = 0.90) == === Description ===
Eight quality management practices were identiﬁed by the authors: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer focus|customer focus]], employee relations, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Management leadership|management leadership]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Process management|process management]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Product or service design|product/service design]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Quality data and reporting|quality data and reporting]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier quality management|supplier quality management]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Training|training]].
=== Items ===
*Amount of feedback provided to employees on their quality performance. (0.84) *Degree of participation in quality decisions by hourly/nonsupervisory employees. (0.88) *Extent to which building quality awareness among employees is ongoing. (0.87) *Extent to which employees are recognized for superior quality performance. (0.75)
All items were adapted from Saraph et al. (1989).
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.06.002 Kaynak/Hartley (2008): A replication and extension of quality management into the supply chain. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 26, No. 4, pp. 468–489.]
{{BookCat}}

== Management leadership (alpha = 0.94; composite reliability = 0.93) == === Description ===
Eight quality management practices were identiﬁed by the authors: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer focus|customer focus]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee relations|employee relations]], management leadership, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Process management|process management]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Product or service design|product/service design]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Quality data and reporting|quality data and reporting]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier quality management|supplier quality management]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Training|training]].
=== Items ===
*Degree to which organization top management (top organization executive and major department heads) is evaluated for quality performance. (0.81) *Degree of participation by major department heads in the quality improvement process. (0.79) *Extent to which the organizational top management has objectives for quality performance. (0.88) *Comprehensiveness of the goal-setting process for quality within the organization. (0.88) *Amount of review of quality issues in organizational top management meetings. (0.81) *Degree to which the organizational top management considers quality improvement as a way to increase proﬁts. (0.81)
All items were adapted from Saraph et al. (1989).
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.06.002 Kaynak/Hartley (2008): A replication and extension of quality management into the supply chain. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 26, No. 4, pp. 468–489.]
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Quality leadership|Quality leadership]] *[[Handbook of Management Scales/Top management support|Top management support]]
{{BookCat}}

== Process management (alpha = 0.82; composite reliability = 0.81) == === Description ===
Eight quality management practices were identiﬁed by the authors: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer focus|customer focus]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee relations|employee relations]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Management leadership|management leadership]], process management, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Product or service design|product/service design]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Quality data and reporting|quality data and reporting]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier quality management|supplier quality management]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Training|training]].
=== Items ===
*Extent to which inspection, review, or checking of work is automated. (0.64) *Stability of production schedule/work distribution. (0.68) *Degree of automation of the process. (0.62) *Extent to which process design is "foolproof" and minimizes the chances of employee errors. (0.81) *Extent to which statistical techniques are used in order to reduce variance in processes. (0.64)
Items 1–4 were adapted from Saraph et al. (1989); item 5 was adopted from Anderson et al. (1995).
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.06.002 Kaynak/Hartley (2008): A replication and extension of quality management into the supply chain. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 26, No. 4, pp. 468–489.]
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/New service development process focus|New service development process focus]] *[[Handbook of Management Scales/Process control|Process control]]
== Process management (composite reliability = 0.89) == === Description ===
The authors identify improvement and innovation as two critical plant level capabilities. These capabilities are each conceptualized as a second-order factor and measured through a distinct bundle of routines. The following routines underlying improvement capabilities are identified: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Continuous improvement|continuous improvement]], process management, and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Leadership involvement in quality|leadership involvement in quality]]. The routines closely related to improvement capability are: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Search for new technologies|search for new technologies]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Cross-functional product design|cross-functional product design]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Processes and equipment development|processes and equipment development]]. The items to measure each routine were selected based on a review of the relevant literature. Items were included that have been used in prior studies. A panel of five academic researchers and managers with expertise in manufacturing operations reviewed each of the items.
=== Definition ===
Process management is based on the view that an organization consists of systems of interrelated processes. It typically involves efforts to map, improve, and adhere to organizational processes.
=== Items ===
*A large percent of the processes on the shop floor are currently under statistical quality control. *We make extensive use of statistical techniques to reduce variance in processes. *We use charts to determine whether our manufacturing processes are in control. *We monitor our processes using statistical process control.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.11.001 Peng et al. (2008): Linking routines to operations capabilities: A new perspective. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 26, No. 6, pp. 730-748.] Based on: Cua et al. (2001) and Ketokivi and Schroeder (2004).
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Handbook of Management Scales/Product or service design

revision.comment: Created page with '== Product/service design (alpha = 0.93; composite reliability = 0.94) == === Description === Eight quality management practices were identiﬁed by the authors: [[Handbook of M...'
revision.text:
== Product/service design (alpha = 0.93; composite reliability = 0.94) == === Description ===
Eight quality management practices were identiﬁed by the authors: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer focus|customer focus]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee relations|employee relations]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Management leadership|management leadership]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Process management|process management]], product/service design, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Quality data and reporting|quality data and reporting]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier quality management|supplier quality management]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Training|training]].
=== Items ===
*Thoroughness of new product/service design reviews before the product/service is produced and marketed. (0.89) *Coordination among affected departments in the product/service development process. (0.93) *Quality of new products/services emphasized in relation to cost or schedule objectives. (0.87) *Extent to which implementation/producibility is considered in the product/service design process. (0.86)
All items were adapted from Saraph et al. (1989).
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.06.002 Kaynak/Hartley (2008): A replication and extension of quality management into the supply chain. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 26, No. 4, pp. 468–489.]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Handbook of Management Scales/Quality data and reporting

revision.comment: Created page with '== Quality data and reporting (alpha = 0.91; composite reliability = 0.90) == === Description === Eight quality management practices were identiﬁed by the authors: [[Handbook ...'
revision.text:
== Quality data and reporting (alpha = 0.91; composite reliability = 0.90) == === Description ===
Eight quality management practices were identiﬁed by the authors: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer focus|customer focus]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee relations|employee relations]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Management leadership|management leadership]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Process management|process management]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Product or service design|product/service design]], quality data and reporting, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier quality management|supplier quality management]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Training|training]].
=== Items ===
*Availability of quality data (error rates, defect rates, scrap, defects, etc.). (0.80) *Timeliness of the quality data. (0.84) *Extent to which quality data (cost of quality, defects, errors, scrap, etc.) are used as tools to manage quality. (0.91) *Availability of procedures to ensure the reliability and improvement of data gathering. (0.76)
Items 1–3 were adapted from Saraph et al. (1989); item 4 was adapted from Black and Porter (1996).
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.06.002 Kaynak/Hartley (2008): A replication and extension of quality management into the supply chain. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 26, No. 4, pp. 468–489.]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier quality management

revision.text:
== Supplier quality management (alpha = 0.84; composite reliability = 0.83) == === Description ===
Eight quality management practices were identiﬁed by the authors: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer focus|customer focus]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee relations|employee relations]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Management leadership|management leadership]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Process management|process management]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Product or service design|product/service design]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Quality data and reporting|quality data and reporting]], supplier quality management, and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Training|training]].
=== Items ===
*Extent to which long-term relationships are offered to suppliers. (0.56) *Reduction in the number of suppliers since implementing just-in-time purchasing and/or total quality management. (0.61) *Extent to which suppliers are evaluated according to quality, delivery performance, and price, in that order. (0.75) *Extent to which suppliers are selected based on quality rather than price or delivery schedule. (0.75) *Thoroughness of your organization’s supplier rating system. (0.74) *Involvement of the supplier in your product/service development process. (0.64)
Items 1, 4–6 were adapted from Saraph et al. (1989); items 2 and 3 were developed by Kaynak (1997).
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.06.002 Kaynak/Hartley (2008): A replication and extension of quality management into the supply chain. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 26, No. 4, pp. 468–489.]
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier development|Supplier development]] *[[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier evaluation systems|Supplier evaluation systems]]
== Supplier quality management (alpha = 0.78) == === Description ===
Through a detailed analysis of the literature, twelve constructs of integrated quality management strategies were identified: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Top management commitment|top management commitment]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer focus|customer focus]], supplier quality management, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Design quality management|design quality management]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Benchmarking|benchmarking]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Statistical process control usage|SPC usage]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Internal quality information usage|internal quality information usage]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee empowerment|employee empowerment]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee involvement|employee involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee training|employee training]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Product quality|product quality]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier performance|supplier performance]]. Using a survey of 371 manufacturing firms, the constructs were then empirically tested and validated. For this purpose a confirmatory factor analysis approach was used.
=== Items ===
Answer with respect to a critical component of the primary product.
*Quality is a more important criterion than price in selecting suppliers of the major component. *Our supplier rating system considers the supplier’s engineering capability. *Our supplier rating system considers the supplier’s financial stability. *Our supplier rating system considers the supplier’s delivery performance. *We provide technical assistance to our suppliers of this component. *We are more interested in developing a long-term relationship with these suppliers than reducing prices.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1540-5915.1996.tb00842.x Ahire et al. (1996): Development and Validation of TQM Implementation Constructs. Decision Sciences, Vol. 27, No. 1, pp. 23-56.]
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier development|Supplier development]] *[[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier evaluation systems|Supplier evaluation systems]]
{{BookCat}}

== Training (alpha = 0.90; composite reliability = 0.90) == === Description ===
Eight quality management practices were identiﬁed by the authors: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer focus|customer focus]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee relations|employee relations]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Management leadership|management leadership]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Process management|process management]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Product or service design|product/service design]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Quality data and reporting|quality data and reporting]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier quality management|supplier quality management]], and training.
=== Items ===
*Speciﬁc work-skills training (technical and vocational) given to hourly employees throughout the organization. (0.79) *Quality-related training given to hourly employees throughout the organization. (0.91) *Quality-related training given to managers and supervisors throughout the organization. (0.89)
All items were adapted from Saraph et al. (1989).
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.06.002 Kaynak/Hartley (2008): A replication and extension of quality management into the supply chain. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 26, No. 4, pp. 468–489.]
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee training|Employee training]]
{{BookCat}}

<noinclude>
 {{Ada/Navigation}}
 __TOC__
 </noinclude>

Ada '''streams'''  are a  powerful I/O mechanism that allows reading and writing any type of object to any type of "''medium''" (e.g., a network connection, a file on a disk, a magnetic tape, a memory buffer).  Streams are somewhat obscure for a beginner; this is because of the "double generality": generality about the object to be written/read and generality about the medium involved.  The objective of this section is to give an intuitive introduction to Ada streams, skipping some of the finer details.  The reader is referred for a more precise and detailed description of Ada streams to the Ada Reference Manual, in particular {{Ada/RM|13|13|title=Streams}}.

== Concepts == 

The language designers split the problem of writing an object over a medium into two sub-problems:

# Convert the object in a sequence of bits 
# Write the bits over the stream

Note that the first step depends only on the object to be sent and not on the actual medium.  On the other hand, the details of the second step depend only on the employed medium and not on the object type.

Similarly, in order to "read" an object from a network connection one must

# Read a block of bits from the stream
# Parse the read block and convert it into an object

Note again that the first step depends only on the medium, while the second one depends only on the object type.


== Abstract streams ==

The abstract model for an Ada stream is, basically, a sequence of ''raw data'' (Stream_Element) that can be read and written in blocks.  This abstract view is formalized in the Stream package definition (from RM {{Ada/RM|13|13|1|title=The Package Streams.}} with some omissions and comments added) 

   {{Ada/kw|package}} Ada.Streams {{Ada/kw|is}}
   
      {{Ada/kw|type}} Root_Stream_Type {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|abstract}} {{Ada/kw|tagged}} {{Ada/kw|limited}} {{Ada/kw|private}};
   
      {{Ada/--|Elementary piece of data.  A Stream is a sequence of Stream_Element}}
      {{Ada/kw|type}} Stream_Element {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|mod}} ''implementation defined'';
    
      {{Ada/kw|type}} Stream_Element_Offset {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|range}} ''implementation defined'';
    
      {{Ada/--|A block of data}}
      {{Ada/kw|type}} Stream_Element_Array {{Ada/kw|is}} 
          {{Ada/kw|array}} (Stream_Element_Offset {{Ada/kw|range}} <>) {{Ada/kw|of}} {{Ada/kw|aliased}} Stream_Element;
     
      {{Ada/--|Abstract procedure that reads a block of data}}
      {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Read (
           Stream : {{Ada/kw|in}} {{Ada/kw|out}} Root_Stream_Type;
           Item   : {{Ada/kw|out}} Stream_Element_Array;
           Last   : {{Ada/kw|out}} Stream_Element_Offset) {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|abstract}};
   
      {{Ada/--|Abstract procedure that writes a block of data}}
      {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Write (
           Stream : {{Ada/kw|in}} {{Ada/kw|out}} Root_Stream_Type;
           Item   : {{Ada/kw|in}} Stream_Element_Array) {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|abstract}};
   
   {{Ada/kw|private}}
          ''implementation defined...''
   {{Ada/kw|end}} Ada.Streams;

Since the type Root_Stream_Type is {{Ada/kw|abstract}}, one cannot create objects of type Root_Stream_Type, but must first derive a new type from Root_Stream_Type.   Ada.Streams just specifies the ''minimal'' interface that a stream must grant: with a stream we must be able to

* '''read''' a block of data (with the procedure Read) and 
* '''write''' a block of data (with Write).  

Typically for every new medium (for example, network connections, disk files, memory buffers) one will  derive  a new type specialized to read and write to that medium. Note that both Read and Write are abstract, so that any non-{{Ada/kw|abstract}} type must necessarily override them with new procedures that will take care of the details of reading/writing from/to a specific medium. 

Note that the minimal interface of Ada.Streams does not include, for example, functions to open or close a stream, nor functions to check, say, an End-Of-Stream condition. This is reasonable since the details of the interfaces of those functions depend on the specific medium: a function that opens a stream associated to a file will expect a file name as argument, a function for opening a network stream will probably expect a network address and a function for opening the stream associated to a memory buffer will probably need the address and size of the buffer.  It will be the duty of the package that derives from Root_Stream_Type to define those "auxiliary" functions.

== Serialization functions ==

The second ingredient in the Ada stream system is what we called ''serialization functions'', that is, the functions whose duty is to convert an Ada object to a sequence of Stream_Elements and vice-versa.  Actually, we will see in a moment that the serialization functions do not interact with the caller by passing back and forth arrays of Stream_Element's, rather they interact directly with the streams.

The serialization functions associated to a given type are defined as type attributes.  For every subtype S of a type T, Ada defines the following attributes associated to stream-related functions and procedures

{| class="wikitable"
|-
! Type !! Input !! Output
|-
| Simple || S'Read || S'Write 
|-
| Simple, class-wide  || S'Class'Read || S'Class'Write
|-
| Composite || S'Input || S'Output
|-
| Composite, class-wide || S'Class'Input || S'Class'Output
|}

We will first describe S'Read and S'Write since they are the simplest and, in some sense, the most "primitive" ones.

=== Write attribute ===

Procedure S'Write is defined in {{Ada/RM|13|13|2|title=Stream-Oriented Attributes (3)}} as follows (remember that S is a subtype of type T)

   {{Ada/kw|procedure}} S'Write(
         Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Ada.Streams.Root_Stream_Type'Class;
         Item   : {{Ada/kw|in}}  T);

The duty of S'Write is to convert Item to a sequence of Stream_Elements and write the result on Stream.  Note that Stream is an access to class-wide type Root_Stream_Type'{{Ada/at|Class}}, therefore the programmer can use S'Write with any stream type derived from Root_Stream_Type.

According to {{Ada/RM|13|13|2|title=Stream-Oriented Attributes (9)}}, Ada defines default implementations for S'{{Ada/at|Write}} as follows

* For elementary types (e.g., Integers, Character, Float) the default implementations write a suitable representation of Item to Stream.  That representation is ''implementation dependent'' but, most of the time, this corresponds simply to the in-memory representation.
* For composite types (e.g., record and array) the default implementation writes each component (array entry or record component) using the corresponding S'{{Ada/at|Write}} procedure.  Note that no other information is written.  For example, if Item is an array, the array dimensions are not written; if Item has a discriminant ''with no default value'', the discriminant is not written.  In some sense, S'{{Ada/at|Write}} writes a very "raw" representation of Item to Stream.

Clearly, the default implementation, being dependent on the machine and compiler, can be useful only if the data is written and read by programs compiled with the same compiler.  If the data, for example, is to be sent across the network and read by a program written in another language, running on an unknown architecture, it is important for the programmer to control the format of the data sent over the wire.  Because of this exigence, Ada allows the programmer to override S'{{Ada/at|Write}} (and the other stream-related functions described in the following), using an attribute definition clause (RM {{Ada/RM|13|3}}):

     {{Ada/kw|for}}  S'{{Ada/at|Write}} {{Ada/kw|use}} user_defined_subprogram;

Suppose, for example, a network protocol requires to format data in the following textual length-type-value format

* Integer values are formatted as "<len> i <value>", where <len> is the number of digits used to represent the integer and <value> is the integer expressed in base 10. (For example, the integer 42 would be represented as "2i42")

The following code defines a suitable S'Write procedure for the integer case (Note: for the sake of simplicity, the following code supposes that each Stream_Element is 8 bits long)

    {{Ada/kw|package}} Example {{Ada/kw|is}}
        {{Ada/kw|type}} Int {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|new}} Integer;
        {{Ada/kw|type}} Int_Array {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|array}} (Int {{Ada/kw|range}} <>) of Int;
       
        {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Print (
             Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Ada.Streams.Root_Stream_Type'{{Ada/at|Class}};
             Item   : {{Ada/kw|in}}  Int);
        
        {{Ada/kw|for}} Int'{{Ada/at|Write}} {{Ada/kw|Use}} Print;
    {{Ada/kw|end}} Example;

    {{Ada/kw|package}} {{Ada/kw|body}} Example {{Ada/kw|is}}
      {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Print (
           Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Ada.Streams.Root_Stream_Type'{{Ada/at|Class}};
           Item   : {{Ada/kw|in}}  Int) 
      {{Ada/kw|is}}
           ''-- Convert Item to String (with no trailing space)''
           Value  : String := Trim(Int'Image(Item), Left);
           
           ''-- Convert Value'Length to String (with no trailing space)''
           Len    : String := Trim(Integer'Image(Value'Length), Left);
      
           Descr  : String := Len & 'i' & Value;
           Buffer : Stream_Element_Array (1 .. Stream_Element_Offset (Descr'{{Ada/at|Length}}));
      {{Ada/kw|begin}} 
           ''-- Copy Descr to Buffer''
           {{Ada/kw|for}} I {{Ada/kw|in}} Buffer'{{Ada/at|Range}} {{Ada/kw|loop}}
               Buffer (I) := Stream_Element (Character'{{Ada/at|Pos}} (Descr (Integer (I))));
           {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|loop}}; 
        
           ''-- Write the result to Stream''
           Stream.Write(Buffer);
      {{Ada/kw|end}} Print;
    {{Ada/kw|end}} Example;

Note the structure of Print: first Item is "serialized" in a sequence of Stream_Element (contained in Buffer), then such a sequence is written to Stream by calling the Write method (that will take care of the details of writing on Stream).  Suppose now that one wants to print the description of 42 to the standard output.  The following code can be used 

    {{Ada/kw|with}}  Ada.Text_IO.Text_Streams;
    {{Ada/kw|use}}   Ada.Text_IO;  {{Ada/--|defines Current_Output. See RM {{Ada/RM|A|10|1}}}}
    
    {{Ada/--|Text_Streams.Stream (Current_Output) returns a stream access}}
    {{Ada/--|associated with the file given as parameter}}
    Int'Write (Text_Streams.Stream (Current_Output), 42); 

The result will be "2i42" printed on the standard output.  Note that the following code 

    Int_Array'Write (Text_Streams.Stream (Current_Output), (1=>42, 2=>128, 3=>6)); 

would write on standard output the string "2i42_3i128_1i6" (the '_' are not actually present; they have been added for readability) corresponding to calling Int'Write on 42, 128 and 6 in sequence.  Note that the array dimensions are ''not'' written.

If one wanted to send the same description across a TCP connection, the following code could be used (with GNAT)

     {{Ada/kw|with}} GNAT.Sockets;
     {{Ada/kw|use}}  GNAT;
     ...
     Sock   : Sockets.Socket_Type;
     Server : Sockets.Sock_Addr_Type := ''server address'';
     ...
     Sockets.Create_Socket (Sock);
     Sockets.Connect_Socket (Sock, Server);
     
     {{Ada/--|Here Sock is connected to the remote server}}
     {{Ada/--|Use Sockets.Stream to convert Sock to a stream}}
     
     {{Ada/--|First send the integer 42}}
     Int'Write (Sockets.Stream (Sock), 42);
     
     {{Ada/--|Now send the array}}
     Int_Array'Write (Sockets.Stream (Sock), (1=>42, 2=>128, 3=>6));

=== Read attribute ===

Procedure S'Read is defined in {{Ada/RM|13|13|2|title=Stream-Oriented Attributes (6)}} as follows 

   {{Ada/kw|procedure}} S'Read(
         Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Ada.Streams.Root_Stream_Type'Class;
         Item   : {{Ada/kw|out}}  T);

Its behavior is clearly symmetric to the one of S'Write: S'Read reads one or more Stream_Element from Stream and "parse" them to construct Item.  Similarly to the case of S'Write, Ada defines default implementations for S'Read that the programmer can override by using the attribute definition clause

   {{Ada/kw|for}} S'Read {{Ada/kw|use}} ...

For example, the following procedure could be assigned to type Int with ''{{Ada/kw|for}} Int'Read {{Ada/kw|use}} Parse;''.

   {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Parse (
                    Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Root_Stream_Type'Class;
                    Item   : {{Ada/kw|out}} Int)
   {{Ada/kw|is}}
      Len    : Integer := 0;
      Buffer : Stream_Element_Array (1 .. 1);
      Last   : Stream_Element_Offset;
      Zero   : Stream_Element := Stream_Element (Character'Pos ('0'));
      Nine   : Stream_Element := Stream_Element (Character'Pos ('9'));
   {{Ada/kw|begin}}
      {{Ada/--|Extract the length from the stream}}
      {{Ada/kw|loop}}
         {{Ada/--|Read one element from the stream}}
         Stream.Read (Buffer, Last);
       
         {{Ada/kw|exit}} {{Ada/kw|when}} {{Ada/kw|not}} (Buffer (1) {{Ada/kw|in}} Zero .. Nine);
         Len := Len * 10 + Integer (Buffer (1) - Zero);
      {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|loop}};
      
      {{Ada/--|Check for the correct delimiter}}
      {{Ada/kw|if}} Character'Val (Integer (Buffer (1))) /= 'i' {{Ada/kw|then}}
         {{Ada/kw|raise}} Data_Error;
      {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|if}};
   
      {{Ada/--|Now convert the following Len characters}}
      Item := 0;
      {{Ada/kw|for}} I {{Ada/kw|in}} 1 .. Len {{Ada/kw|loop}}
         Stream.Read (Buffer, Last);
         Item := 10 * Item + Int (Buffer (1) - Zero);
      {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|loop}};
   {{Ada/kw|end}} Parse;

=== Output attribute ===

Procedure S'{{Ada/at|Output}} is defined in {{Ada/RM|13|13|2|title=Stream-Oriented Attributes (19)}} as follows 

   {{Ada/kw|procedure}} S'{{Ada/at|Output}}(
         Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Ada.Streams.Root_Stream_Type'{{Ada/at|Class}};
         Item   : {{Ada/kw|in}}  T);

S'{{Ada/at|Output}} differs from S'{{Ada/at|Write}} in that its default implementation 

* first it writes arrays bound (if S is an array) and discriminants (if S is a record).  
* then it calls S'{{Ada/at|Write}} to write Item itself

Note that the bounds or the discriminant are written '''by calling the respective S'{{Ada/at|Write}} procedures'''.  Therefore, since Int_Array was defined above as an array of Int indexed by Int, the following line 

     Int_Array'Output (Text_Streams.Stream (Current_Output), (1 => 42, 2 => 128, 3 => 6));

would produce (the '_' are added for readability and are not actually present in the output)

     1i1_1i3_2i42_3i128_1i6

Note the array bounds "1i1" and "1i3" at the beginning of the line.

=== Input attribute ===

Procedure S'{{Ada/at|Input}} is defined in {{Ada/RM|13|13|2|title=Stream-Oriented Attributes}} as follows 

   {{Ada/kw|function}} S'Input(
         Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Ada.Streams.Root_Stream_Type'{{Ada/at|Class}})
         {{Ada/kw|return}}  T;

S'{{Ada/at|Input}} is for S'{{Ada/at|Read}} what S'{{Ada/at|Output}} is for S'{{Ada/at|Write}} in the sense that S'{{Ada/at|Read}} 

* first it reads the bounds or the discriminants ('''using the corresponding S'{{Ada/at|Read}}''')
* it uses the read values to create the object to be returned
* it calls the corresponding S'{{Ada/at|Read}} to initialize the object

Note that S'{{Ada/at|Input}} is a function, while S'{{Ada/at|Read}} is a procedure. This is coherent with the fact when S'{{Ada/at|Read}} is called any bound and/or discriminant must be already known, so that the caller can create the object and pass it to S'{{Ada/at|Read}}. With S'{{Ada/at|Input}}, on the other hand, the bounds/discriminants are not known, but read from the stream; therefore, the burden of creating the object is on S'{{Ada/at|Input}}.


=== Class-wide Read and Write ===

Note that S'{{Ada/at|Read}} and S'{{Ada/at|Write}} are not [[Ada Programming/Object Orientation|primitive subprograms]] of S and they cannot be dynamically dispatching, even if S is a tagged type.  In order to allow for dynamical dispatching of S'{{Ada/at|Read}} and S'{{Ada/at|Write}} methods, {{Ada/RM|13|13|2|title=Stream-Oriented Attributes|par=11}} defines procedures

   {{Ada/kw|procedure}} S'{{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Write}}(
      Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Ada.Streams.Root_Stream_Type'Class;
      Item   : {{Ada/kw|in}} T'Class);
   
   {{Ada/kw|procedure}} S'{{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Read}}(
      Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Ada.Streams.Root_Stream_Type'Class;
      Item   : {{Ada/kw|out}} T'Class);

Note that in both cases the type of Item is T'{{Ada/at|Class}}, so Item can be of any type derived from T.  The behavior of those procedures is to dispatch to the actual S'{{Ada/at|Write}} or S'{{Ada/at|Read}} identified by the tag of Item.  See [[Ada Programming/Input Output/Stream Tutorial/Example]] for an example of usage of the class-wide stream attributes S'{{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Read}} and S'{{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Write}}.

=== Class-wide Input and Output ===

Similarly to the case of S'{{Ada/at|Read}} and S'{{Ada/at|Write}}, {{Ada/RM|13|13|2|title=Stream-Oriented Attributes|par=28}} defines the class-wide versions of S'{{Ada/at|Output}} and S'{{Ada/at|Input}}

   {{Ada/kw|procedure}} S'{{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Output}}(
      Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Ada.Streams.Root_Stream_Type'Class;
      Item   : {{Ada/kw|in}} T'{{Ada/at|Class}})
   
   {{Ada/kw|function}} S'{{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Input}}(
      Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Ada.Streams.Root_Stream_Type'Class)
           {{Ada/kw|return}} T'{{Ada/at|Class}};

Their default behavior is almost obvious when one remembers that a tagged type can actually be considered as a record with an "hidden discriminant" 

* '''S'{{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Output}}''' first writes the tag to Stream by first converting it to string and then calling String'{{Ada/at|Output}} on the result.  Successively, S'{{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Output}} dispatches to the subprogram S'{{Ada/at|Output}}  of the specific type identified by the tag.
* '''S'{{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Input}}''' first reads the tag from Stream by first calling String'Input and converting the result to a tag. Successively, S'{{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Input}} dispatches to the subprogram S'{{Ada/at|Input}}  of the specific type identified by the tag.

See {{Ada/RM|13|13|2|title=Stream-Oriented Attributes|par=28}} for a more detailed and precise explanation.  See [[Ada Programming/Libraries/Ada.Streams/Example]] for an example of usage of the class-wide stream attributes.

== See also == 

=== Wikibook === 

* [[Ada Programming]]
* [[Ada Programming/Object Orientation]]

=== Ada 2005 Reference Manual ===

* {{Ada/2005/RM|13|13|1|title=The Package Streams}}

[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Nbenmargi!
[[Image:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for freely-licensed collaboratively-developed [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].'''
You don't need technical skills in order to contribute here. '''[[WB:BOLD|Be bold]]''' contributing and ''[[WB:AGF|assume good faith]]'' about the intentions of others. Remember, this is a ''[[w:wiki|wiki]]'', so you're allowed to change just about anything, and changes can be made easily. Come [[Wikibooks:Reading room/General|introduce yourself]] to everyone, and let us know what [[Wikibooks:Reading room/Projects|interests you]]. If you're coming here from other Wikimedia projects, you should read [[Help:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|our primer for Wikimedians]] to get quickly up-to-speed.
[[Image:Icon apps query.svg|20px]] '''Getting help'''
* See the '''Wikibooks [[Help:Contents|help pages]]''' for common issues, or read [[Using Wikibooks]] for a more user-friendly introduction to the project. * Remember, every edit is saved, so if you make mistakes, you can [[Wikibooks:Reverting|revert]] to an earlier version if needed. * Get help from the community in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]] or in our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * You cannot upload an image until you have been a member for at least '''4 days'''. If your upload is tagged with {{tlx|nld}}, {{tlx|bfu}}, or {{tlx|nfur}}, please read the template message as it explains the violation of [[WB:MEDIA|our media policy]]. Please be sure to provide the required {{tlx|information}}: a [[WB:ICT|license tag]] and source citation are always required; fair use images require a {{tlx|fair use rationale}}. Get help in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]].
[[Image:Transmission icon.png|20px]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[:w:Help:Edit summary|the edit summary]] and [[Help:Show preview|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[Help:Talk page|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
[[Image:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* '''Please make sure you follow our [[WB:NP|naming policy]]''' - modules should be named like Book Title/Chapter Title. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (only become available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To get a page deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason for requesting deletion''}} to the top of the page. * If something you wrote was deleted, please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
If you have any questions, feel free to contact me! --[[User:Girdi|Girdi]] ([[User talk:Girdi|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Girdi|contribs]]) 12:57, 5 February 2011 (UTC)
(P.S. Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)

==Welcome!== [[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome to Wikibooks]]! You do not need to [[WB:LOGIN|log in]] to read or edit books at Wikibooks, but creating an account is quick, free and non-intrusive, requires no personal information, and gives you many benefits, including: * A username of your choice for directly attributing [[Special:Contributions/{{PAGENAME}}|your contributions]]. * A personal user page, a [[WB:TALK|talk page]], and a [[Help:Tracking changes#Watching pages|watchlist]] to monitor pages that interest you. * The ability to [[WB:MOVE|rename]] pages and to [[WB:PREFS|customize]] some aspects of the Wikibooks interface. * People will recognize you as a member of the Wikibooks community, and you will be eligible to [[WB:REVIEW|review]] pages. * Your IP address will be hidden from most users, which may give you a greater sense of security and privacy.
We hope that you choose to join our community as a Wikibookian and [[Special:Userlogin|create an account]].
Feel free to ask any questions on my talk page or in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]]. Be sure to sign your talk page comments with four tildes (<nowiki>~~~~</nowiki>).
Thanks. – [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] <small>[[User talk:Adrignola|discuss]]</small> 13:27, 5 February 2011 (UTC)

page.title: Handbook of Management Scales/Acquiring tacit knowledge through offshore outsourcing

revision.comment: Created page with '== Acquiring tacit knowledge through offshore outsourcing (alpha = 0.905/0.937) == === Items === *We often acquire market development knowledge from the partner through offshore...'
revision.text:
== Acquiring tacit knowledge through offshore outsourcing (alpha = 0.905/0.937) == === Items ===
*We often acquire market development knowledge from the partner through offshore outsourcing. *We often learn operations management skills from the partner through offshore outsourcing. *We learn new product development knowledge of from the partner through offshore outsourcing. *We obtain new and important information from our partner through offshore outsourcing.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.02.011 Li et al. (2008): Transformational offshore outsourcing: Empirical evidence from alliances in China. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 26, No. 2, pp. 257-274.]
{{BookCat}}

== Formal control (alpha = 0.780/0.786) == === Description ===
The authors consider two forms of control, namely formal control and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Social control|social control]].
=== Items ===
*Detailed contract is the most important way to guarantee cooperation success. *The contract is useful to regulate the behavior of partner. *In the process of cooperation, we use ﬁnancial and market indices to evaluate cooperation success. *Detailed cooperative rules have been written in the contract. *Both partners know the cooperative procedures.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.02.011 Li et al. (2008): Transformational offshore outsourcing: Empirical evidence from alliances in China. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 26, No. 2, pp. 257-274.]
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Social control|Social control]]
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Created page with '== Social control (alpha = 0.930/0.703) == === Description === The authors consider two forms of control, namely [[Handbook of Management Scales/Formal control|formal control]] ...'
revision.text:
== Social control (alpha = 0.930/0.703) == === Description ===
The authors consider two forms of control, namely [[Handbook of Management Scales/Formal control|formal control]] and social control.
=== Items ===
*We can trust our partners in the process of cooperation. *The shared vision and values have been built in the cooperation. *We are confident of the capability of our partner. *Without monitoring, the partner would fulﬁll his obligations. *We often communicate ideas about selling, production and servicing with our partner.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.02.011 Li et al. (2008): Transformational offshore outsourcing: Empirical evidence from alliances in China. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 26, No. 2, pp. 257-274.]
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Formal control|Formal control]] *[[Handbook of Management Scales/Trust|Trust]]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Chess Opening Theory/1. d4/1...Nf6/2. c4/2...c5/3. d5/3...b5/4. cxb5/4...a6/5. bxa6/5...Bxa6

revision.text:
{{Chess Opening Theory/Position|= |Benko Gambit| |rd|nd| |qd|kd|bd| |rd|= | | | |pd|pd|pd|pd|pd|= |bd| | | | |nd| | |= | | |pd|pl| | | | |= | | | | | | | | |= | | | | | | | | |= |pl|pl| | |pl|pl|pl|pl|= |rl|nl|bl|ql|kl|bl|nl|rl|= |moves=1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 c5 3.d5 b5 |eco=A57-A59 |parent=[[Chess/Benoni Defence|Benoni Defence]] }} = Benko Gambit = === 5. ... Bxa6 === The most common move. 5... g6 is more flexible. Here in case white continues b3 to oppose the black bishop on g7, black can't capture with the knight on a6 to pressurise d5. ==Theory table== {{Chess Opening Theory/Table}}. '''1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 c5 3. d5 b5 4. cxb5 a6 5. bxa6 Bxa6'''
6 7
[[/6. g3|g3]]

g6		 b3!
Bg7		 Bb2
0-0		 Nh3
Nbd7		 0-0
+=

page.title: Chess Opening Theory/1. d4/1...Nf6/2. c4/2...g6/3. Nc3/3...Bg7/4. e4/4...d6/5. f4

revision.comment: [[WB:REVERT|Reverted]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/68.100.132.53|68.100.132.53]] ([[User talk:68.100.132.53|talk]]) to last version by Tempodivalse
revision.text:
{{Chess Opening Theory/Position|= |King's Indian Defence| |rd|nd|bd|qd|kd| | |rd|= |pd|pd|pd| |pd|pd|bd|pd|= | | | |pd| |nd|pd| |= | | | | | | | | |= | | |pl|pl|pl|pl| | |= | | |nl| | | | | |= |pl|pl| | | | |pl|pl|= |rl| |bl|ql|kl|bl|nl|rl|= || }} = King's Indian Defence = === 5. f4 === The '''Four Pawns Attack''' is the most aggressive line for white in the King's Indian. White creates a massive pawn centre and has full control over the middle of the board ... for now. This is a dangerous line for black, and if the second player doesn't play correctly he will be knocked off the board by white's advancing army! However, if black can survive the initial onslaught, he will have the better game since white will have many weak squares in his camp that his pawns can't defend. For this reason, the Four Pawns Attack isn't seen frequently at the highest levels of chess, although it's still very viable at the amateur level. ==Theory table== {{Chess Opening Theory/Table}}. '''1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. Nc3 Bg7 4. e4 d6 5. f4'''
Four Pawns Attack ...
[[/5...O-O|O-O]]		 Nf3
c5		 d5
e6		 Be2
exd5		 =∞
{{ChessMid}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Wikipedia|King's Indian Defence}} {{BCO2}} {{Chess Opening Theory/Footer}}

Density is the mass per unit volume of a substance. The formula for density is: density = mass/volume.
The unit for mass is kilograms (kg)/grams (g) and volume in centimetres cubed (cm<sup>3</sup>) or metres cubed (m<sup>3</sup>).
Example 1. A stone of mass 20 kg with volume 4 cm<sup>3</sup> calculate its density. density = mass/volume = 20kg/4cm3 = 5kg/cm3
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Created page with '== Continuous flow (alpha > 0.7; composite reliability = 0.75; average variance extracted = 0.45) == === Description === The research takes a step toward clarifying the concept ...'
revision.text:
== Continuous flow (alpha > 0.7; composite reliability = 0.75; average variance extracted = 0.45) == === Description ===
The research takes a step toward clarifying the concept of lean production and develops and validates a multi-dimensional measure of lean production. The 10 distinct dimensions of a lean system are continuous flow, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer involvement|customer involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee involvement|employee involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/JIT delivery by suppliers|JIT delivery by suppliers]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Pull|pull]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Set up time reduction|set up time reduction]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Statistical process control|statistical process control]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier development|supplier development]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier feedback|supplier feedback]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Total productive and preventive maintenance|total productive/preventive maintenance]].
=== Definition ===
Lean production is an integrated socio-technical system whose main objective is to eliminate waste by concurrently reducing or minimizing supplier, customer, and internal variability. This dimension of lean production is about establishing mechanisms that enable and ease the continuous ﬂow of products.
=== Items ===
Please indicate the extent of implementation of each of the following practices in your plant. (1) no implementation; (2) little implementation; (3) some implementation; (4) extensive implementation; (5) complete implementation.
*Products are classified into groups with similar processing requirements. *Products are classified into groups with similar routing requirements. *Equipment is grouped to produce a continuous flow of families of products. *Families of products determine our factory layout.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.01.019 Shah/Ward (2007): Deﬁning and developing measures of lean production. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 25, No. 4, pp. 785-805.]
=== Comments ===
Average variance extracted is too low. Some items appear to be formative rather than reflective.
{{BookCat}}

== Employee involvement (alpha > 0.7; composite reliability = 0.83; average variance extracted = 0.50) == === Description ===
The research takes a step toward clarifying the concept of lean production and develops and validates a multi-dimensional measure of lean production. The 10 distinct dimensions of a lean system are [[Handbook of Management Scales/Continuous flow|continuous flow]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer involvement|customer involvement]], employee involvement, [[Handbook of Management Scales/JIT delivery by suppliers|JIT delivery by suppliers]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Pull|pull]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Set up time reduction|set up time reduction]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Statistical process control|statistical process control]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier development|supplier development]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier feedback|supplier feedback]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Total productive and preventive maintenance|total productive/preventive maintenance]].
=== Definition ===
Lean production is an integrated socio-technical system whose main objective is to eliminate waste by concurrently reducing or minimizing supplier, customer, and internal variability. This dimension of lean production is about the employees’ role in problem solving, and their cross functional character.
=== Items ===
Please indicate the extent of implementation of each of the following practices in your plant. (1) no implementation; (2) little implementation; (3) some implementation; (4) extensive implementation; (5) complete implementation.
*Shop-floor employees are key to problem solving teams *Shop-floor employees drive suggestion programs *Shop-floor employees lead product/process improvement efforts *Shop-floor employees undergo cross functional training
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.01.019 Shah/Ward (2007): Deﬁning and developing measures of lean production. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 25, No. 4, pp. 785-805.]
== Employee involvement (alpha = 0.79) == === Description ===
Through a detailed analysis of the literature, twelve constructs of integrated quality management strategies were identified: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Top management commitment|top management commitment]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer focus|customer focus]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier quality management|supplier quality management]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Design quality management|design quality management]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Benchmarking|benchmarking]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Statistical process control usage|SPC usage]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Internal quality information usage|internal quality information usage]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee empowerment|employee empowerment]], employee involvement, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee training|employee training]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Product quality|product quality]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier performance|supplier performance]]. Using a survey of 371 manufacturing firms, the constructs were then empirically tested and validated. For this purpose a confirmatory factor analysis approach was used.
=== Items ===
*Cross-functional teams are often used. *All employee suggestions are evaluated. *Most employee suggestions are implemented.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1540-5915.1996.tb00842.x Ahire et al. (1996): Development and Validation of TQM Implementation Constructs. Decision Sciences, Vol. 27, No. 1, pp. 23-56.]
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Leadership involvement in quality|Leadership involvement in quality]]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Handbook of Management Scales/JIT delivery by suppliers

revision.comment: Created page with '== JIT delivery by suppliers (alpha > 0.7; composite reliability = 0.66; average variance extracted = 0.39) == === Description === The research takes a step toward clarifying th...'
revision.text:
== JIT delivery by suppliers (alpha > 0.7; composite reliability = 0.66; average variance extracted = 0.39) == === Description ===
The research takes a step toward clarifying the concept of lean production and develops and validates a multi-dimensional measure of lean production. The 10 distinct dimensions of a lean system are [[Handbook of Management Scales/Continuous flow|continuous flow]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer involvement|customer involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee involvement|employee involvement]], JIT delivery by suppliers, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Pull|pull]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Set up time reduction|set up time reduction]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Statistical process control|statistical process control]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier development|supplier development]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier feedback|supplier feedback]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Total productive and preventive maintenance|total productive/preventive maintenance]].
=== Definition ===
Lean production is an integrated socio-technical system whose main objective is to eliminate waste by concurrently reducing or minimizing supplier, customer, and internal variability. This dimension of lean production is about ensuring that suppliers deliver the right quantity at the right time in the right place.
=== Items ===
Please indicate the extent of implementation of each of the following practices in your plant. (1) no implementation; (2) little implementation; (3) some implementation; (4) extensive implementation; (5) complete implementation.
*Suppliers are directly involved in the new product development process. *Our key suppliers deliver to plant on JIT basis. *We have a formal supplier certification program.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.01.019 Shah/Ward (2007): Deﬁning and developing measures of lean production. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 25, No. 4, pp. 785-805.]
=== Comments ===
Both composite reliability and average variance extracted are too low. Especially for the first and third item it is questionable if the scale really measures just-in-time delivery.
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Created page with '== Pull (alpha > 0.7; composite reliability = 0.88; average variance extracted = 0.66) == === Description === The research takes a step toward clarifying the concept of lean pro...'
revision.text:
== Pull (alpha > 0.7; composite reliability = 0.88; average variance extracted = 0.66) == === Description ===
The research takes a step toward clarifying the concept of lean production and develops and validates a multi-dimensional measure of lean production. The 10 distinct dimensions of a lean system are [[Handbook of Management Scales/Continuous flow|continuous flow]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer involvement|customer involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee involvement|employee involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/JIT delivery by suppliers|JIT delivery by suppliers]], pull, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Set up time reduction|set up time reduction]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Statistical process control|statistical process control]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier development|supplier development]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier feedback|supplier feedback]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Total productive and preventive maintenance|total productive/preventive maintenance]].
=== Definition ===
Lean production is an integrated socio-technical system whose main objective is to eliminate waste by concurrently reducing or minimizing supplier, customer, and internal variability. This dimension of lean production is about facilitating JIT production including kanban cards which serves as a signal to start or stop production.
=== Items ===
Please indicate the extent of implementation of each of the following practices in your plant. (1) no implementation; (2) little implementation; (3) some implementation; (4) extensive implementation; (5) complete implementation.
*Production is "pulled" by the shipment of finished goods. *Production at stations is "pulled" by the current demand of the next station. *We use a "pull" production system. *We use Kanban, squares, or containers of signals for production control.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.01.019 Shah/Ward (2007): Deﬁning and developing measures of lean production. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 25, No. 4, pp. 785-805.]
=== Comments ===
The last item might be formative rather than reflective, because it doesn't react to other signals than those mentioned.
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Handbook of Management Scales/Set up time reduction

revision.comment: Created page with '== Set up time reduction (alpha > 0.7; composite reliability = 0.75; average variance extracted = 0.51) == === Description === The research takes a step toward clarifying the co...'
revision.text:
== Set up time reduction (alpha > 0.7; composite reliability = 0.75; average variance extracted = 0.51) == === Description ===
The research takes a step toward clarifying the concept of lean production and develops and validates a multi-dimensional measure of lean production. The 10 distinct dimensions of a lean system are [[Handbook of Management Scales/Continuous flow|continuous flow]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer involvement|customer involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee involvement|employee involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/JIT delivery by suppliers|JIT delivery by suppliers]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Pull|pull]], set up time reduction, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Statistical process control|statistical process control]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier development|supplier development]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier feedback|supplier feedback]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Total productive and preventive maintenance|total productive/preventive maintenance]].
=== Definition ===
Lean production is an integrated socio-technical system whose main objective is to eliminate waste by concurrently reducing or minimizing supplier, customer, and internal variability. This dimension of lean production is about reducing process downtime between product changeovers.
=== Items ===
Please indicate the extent of implementation of each of the following practices in your plant. (1) no implementation; (2) little implementation; (3) some implementation; (4) extensive implementation; (5) complete implementation.
*Our employees practice setups to reduce the time required. *We are working to lower setup times in our plant. *We have low setup times of equipment in our plant.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.01.019 Shah/Ward (2007): Deﬁning and developing measures of lean production. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 25, No. 4, pp. 785-805.]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Handbook of Management Scales/Statistical process control

revision.text:
== Statistical process control (alpha > 0.7; composite reliability = 0.86; average variance extracted = 0.60) == === Description ===
The research takes a step toward clarifying the concept of lean production and develops and validates a multi-dimensional measure of lean production. The 10 distinct dimensions of a lean system are [[Handbook of Management Scales/Continuous flow|continuous flow]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer involvement|customer involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee involvement|employee involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/JIT delivery by suppliers|JIT delivery by suppliers]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Pull|pull]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Set up time reduction|set up time reduction]], statistical process control, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier development|supplier development]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier feedback|supplier feedback]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Total productive and preventive maintenance|total productive/preventive maintenance]].
=== Definition ===
Lean production is an integrated socio-technical system whose main objective is to eliminate waste by concurrently reducing or minimizing supplier, customer, and internal variability. This dimension of lean production is about ensuring each process will supply defect free units to subsequent process.
=== Items ===
Please indicate the extent of implementation of each of the following practices in your plant. (1) no implementation; (2) little implementation; (3) some implementation; (4) extensive implementation; (5) complete implementation.
*Large number of equipment/processes on shop floor are currently under SPC *Extensive use of statistical techniques to reduce process variance *Charts showing defect rates are used as tools on the shop-floor *We use fishbone type diagrams to identify causes of quality problems *We conduct process capability studies before product launch
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.01.019 Shah/Ward (2007): Deﬁning and developing measures of lean production. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 25, No. 4, pp. 785-805.]
=== Comments ===
Some items (especially 3 and 4) appear to be formative rather than reflective.
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Statistical process control usage|Statistical process control usage]]
{{BookCat}}

== Supplier development (alpha > 0.7; composite reliability = 0.74; average variance extracted = 0.33) == === Description ===
The research takes a step toward clarifying the concept of lean production and develops and validates a multi-dimensional measure of lean production. The 10 distinct dimensions of a lean system are [[Handbook of Management Scales/Continuous flow|continuous flow]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer involvement|customer involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee involvement|employee involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/JIT delivery by suppliers|JIT delivery by suppliers]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Pull|pull]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Set up time reduction|set up time reduction]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Statistical process control|statistical process control]], supplier development, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier feedback|supplier feedback]], and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Total productive and preventive maintenance|total productive/preventive maintenance]].
=== Definition ===
Lean production is an integrated socio-technical system whose main objective is to eliminate waste by concurrently reducing or minimizing supplier, customer, and internal variability. This dimension of lean production is about developing suppliers so they can be more involved in the production process of the focal firm.
=== Items ===
Please indicate the extent of implementation of each of the following practices in your plant. (1) no implementation; (2) little implementation; (3) some implementation; (4) extensive implementation; (5) complete implementation.
*Our suppliers are contractually committed to annual cost reductions. *Our key suppliers are located in close proximity to our plants. *We have corporate level communication on important issues with key suppliers. *We take active steps to reduce the number of suppliers in each category. *Our key suppliers manage our inventory. *We evaluate suppliers on the basis of total cost and not per unit price.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.01.019 Shah/Ward (2007): Deﬁning and developing measures of lean production. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 25, No. 4, pp. 785-805.]
=== Comments ===
Average variance extracted is too low. The items are quite heterogenous and sometimes they appear to be too far from measuring supplier development.
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier evaluation systems|Supplier evaluation systems]] *[[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier quality management|Supplier quality management]]
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Created page with '== Supplier feedback (alpha > 0.7; composite reliability = 0.77; average variance extracted = 0.53) == === Description === The research takes a step toward clarifying the concep...'
revision.text:
== Supplier feedback (alpha > 0.7; composite reliability = 0.77; average variance extracted = 0.53) == === Description ===
The research takes a step toward clarifying the concept of lean production and develops and validates a multi-dimensional measure of lean production. The 10 distinct dimensions of a lean system are [[Handbook of Management Scales/Continuous flow|continuous flow]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer involvement|customer involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee involvement|employee involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/JIT delivery by suppliers|JIT delivery by suppliers]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Pull|pull]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Set up time reduction|set up time reduction]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Statistical process control|statistical process control]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier development|supplier development]], supplier feedback, and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Total productive and preventive maintenance|total productive/preventive maintenance]].
=== Definition ===
Lean production is an integrated socio-technical system whose main objective is to eliminate waste by concurrently reducing or minimizing supplier, customer, and internal variability. This dimension of lean production is about providing regular feedback to suppliers about their performance.
=== Items ===
Please indicate the extent of implementation of each of the following practices in your plant. (1) no implementation; (2) little implementation; (3) some implementation; (4) extensive implementation; (5) complete implementation.
*We frequently are in close contact with our suppliers. *We give our suppliers feedback on quality and delivery performance. *We strive to establish long-term relationship with our suppliers.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.01.019 Shah/Ward (2007): Deﬁning and developing measures of lean production. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 25, No. 4, pp. 785-805.]
=== Comments ===
Only the second item is about feedback rather than relationship. It is therefore questionable if this scale really measures what it is intended to measure.
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Handbook of Management Scales/Total productive and preventive maintenance

revision.comment: Created page with '== Total productive/preventive maintenance (alpha > 0.7; composite reliability = 0.77; average variance extracted = 0.45) == === Description === The research takes a step toward...'
revision.text:
== Total productive/preventive maintenance (alpha > 0.7; composite reliability = 0.77; average variance extracted = 0.45) == === Description ===
The research takes a step toward clarifying the concept of lean production and develops and validates a multi-dimensional measure of lean production. The 10 distinct dimensions of a lean system are [[Handbook of Management Scales/Continuous flow|continuous flow]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Customer involvement|customer involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Employee involvement|employee involvement]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/JIT delivery by suppliers|JIT delivery by suppliers]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Pull|pull]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Set up time reduction|set up time reduction]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Statistical process control|statistical process control]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier development|supplier development]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Supplier feedback|supplier feedback]], and total productive/preventive maintenance.
=== Definition ===
Lean production is an integrated socio-technical system whose main objective is to eliminate waste by concurrently reducing or minimizing supplier, customer, and internal variability. This dimension of lean production is about addressing equipment downtime through total productive maintenance and thus achieve a high level of equipment availability.
=== Items ===
Please indicate the extent of implementation of each of the following practices in your plant. (1) no implementation; (2) little implementation; (3) some implementation; (4) extensive implementation; (5) complete implementation.
*We dedicate a portion of everyday to planned equipment maintenance related activities *We maintain all our equipment regularly *We maintain excellent records of all equipment maintenance related activities *We post equipment maintenance records on shop floor for active sharing with employees
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jom.2007.01.019 Shah/Ward (2007): Deﬁning and developing measures of lean production. Journal of Operations Management, Vol. 25, No. 4, pp. 785-805.]
=== Comments ===
Average variance extracted is too low. The last item might not measure the construct.
{{BookCat}}

== Identifiers and keywords ==
The rexx interpreter is case insensitive. This means that identifier names and keywords containing lowercase letters are considered to be the same as those containing uppercase letters:
/* These variables are all the same */
count = 1 Count = COUNT + 1 say count
== Literal Strings ==
Lettercase is preserved within literal strings:
say 'Hello!' /* Hello! */ SAY 'HELLO!' /* HELLO! */
== Comparison of Strings ==
In rexx, the comparative operators are case sensitive , so strings containing differing letter cases will not be interpreted as matching strings:
if "abc" = "ABC" then say "The strings are the same!" /* This does not happen because the strings are not the same */
{{BookCat}}
