[[::User:Kayau|Kayau]] {{toolbar|separator=dot |[[::User talk:Kayau|discuss]] |[[::Special:Emailuser/Kayau|email]] |[[::Special:Contributions/Kayau|contribs]] |[{{fullurl::Special:Log|user={{urlencode:Kayau}}}} logs] |[http://toolserver.org/~soxred93/pcount/index.php?name{{=}}{{urlencode:Kayau}}&lang{{=}}en&wiki{{=}}wikibooks count] }} 15:48, 22 January 2011 (UTC)

page.title: High School Trigonometry/Circular Functions of Real Numbers

revision.text:
{{TOC right}}
In this lesson you will view the trigonometric ratios of angles of rotation around the coordinate grid as a continuous, circular function. The connection will be made between how the ratios change as the angle of rotation increases or decreases, and how the graph of the function depicts that change.
==Learning Objectives== * Identify the 6 basic trigonometric ratios as continuous functions of the angle of rotation around the origin. * Identify the domain and range of the six basic trigonometric functions. * Identify the radian and degree measure, as well as the coordinates of points on the unit circle for the quadrant angles, and those with reference angles of 30°, 45°, and 60°.
==''y'' = sin(''x''), The Sine Graph== By now, you have become very familiar with the specific values of sine, cosine, and tangents for certain angles of rotation around the coordinate grid. In mathematics, we can often learn a lot by looking at how one quantity changes as we consistently vary another. In this case, what will happen to the value of, let's say, the sine of the angle as we gradually rotate around the coordinate grid. We would be looking at the sine value as a function of the angle of rotation around the coordinate grid. We refer to any such function as a circular function, because they can be defined using the unit circle. First of all, you may recall from earlier sections that the sine of an angle in standard position in the coordinate grid is the ratio of <math>\tfrac{y}{r}</math>, where ''y'' is the ''y''-coordinate of any point on the angle and ''r'' is the distance from the origin to that point.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 1.svg|500px]]
Because the ratios are the same for a given angle, regardless of the length of the radius ''r'', we can use the '''unit circle''' to make things a little more convenient.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 2.svg|500px]]
The denominator is now 1, so we have the simpler expression sin(''θ'') = ''y''. The advantage to this is that we can use the ''y''-coordinate of the point on the unit circle to trace the value of sin(''θ'') through a complete rotation. Imagine if we start at 0 and then rotate counter-clockwise through gradually increasing angles. Since the ''y''-coordinate is the sine value, watch the height of the point as you rotate.
Through Quadrant I that height gets larger, starting at 0, increasing quickly at first, then slower until the angle reaches 90°, at which point, the height is at its maximum value, 1.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 3.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 4.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 5.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 6.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 7.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 8.svg|400px]]
As you rotate into the third quadrant, the change in the height now reverses itself and starts to decrease towards 0.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 9.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 10.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 11.svg|400px]]
When you start to rotate into the third and fourth quadrants, the length of the segment increases, but this time in a negative direction, growing to −1 at 270° and heading back toward 0 at 360°.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 12.svg|400px]]
After one complete rotation, even though the angle continues to increase, the sine values will simply repeat themselves. The same would have been true if we chose to rotate clockwise to investigate negative angles, and this explains why the sine function is periodic. The period is 2π radians or 360°, because that is the angle measure required before the sine of the angle will simply repeat the previous sequence of values.
Let's translate this circular motion into a graph of the sine value vs. the angle of rotation. The following sequence of pictures demonstrates the connection. As the angle of rotation increases, watch the ''y''-coordinate of the point on the angle as it traces horizontally. Ignore the values along the horizontal axis at this point as they just relative. What is important is that you make the connection between the circular rotation and the change in the height of the point.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 13.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 14.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 15.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 16.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 17.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 18.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 19.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 20.svg|500px]]
Notice that once we rotate around once, the point traces back over the same values again. The red curve that you see is one period of a sine "wave". The below animation shows this happen in "real time".
:[[File:ComplexSinInATimeAxe.gif]]
Let's look at some specific values so we can graph the sine function more precisely. Since we already know what happens in between, you can draw a fairly accurate sketch by plotting the points for the quadrant angles (0, <math>\tfrac{\pi}{2}</math>, π, <math>\tfrac{3\pi}{2}</math>, 2π).
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 21.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 22.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 23.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 24.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 25.svg|400px]]
The value of sin(''θ'') goes from 0 to 1 to 0 to −1 and back to 0. Graphed along a horizontal axis showing ''θ'', it would look like this:
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 26.svg|500px]]
Filling in the gaps in between and allowing for multiple rotations as well as negative angles results in the graph of ''y'' = sin(''x'') where ''x'' is any angle of rotation (usually expressed in radians):
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 27.svg|500px]]
As we have already mentioned, sin(''x'') has a period of 2π. You should also note that the ''y''-values never go above 1 or below −1, so the '''range''' of a sine wave is {−1 ≤ ''y'' ≤ 1}. Because we can continue to spin around the circle forever, there is no restriction on the angle ''x'', so the '''domain''' of sin(''x'') is all reals.
==''y'' = cos(''x''), The Cosine Graph== In [[../Trigonometry and Right Angles|chapter 1]], you learned that sine and cosine are very closely related. The cosine of an angle is the same as the sine of the complementary angle. So, it should not surprise you that sine and cosine waves are very similar in that they are both periodic with a period of 2π, a range from −1 to 1, and a domain of all real angles.
The cosine of an angle is the ratio of <math>\tfrac{x}{r}</math>, so in the unit circle, the cosine is the ''x''-coordinate of the point of rotation. If we trace the x−coordinate through a rotation, you will notice the change in the distance is similar to sin(x), but cos(''x'') starts in a different place. The x−coordinate of a 0° angle is 1 and the ''x''-coordinate for 90° is 0, so the cosine value is decreasing from 1 to 0 through the 1<sup>st</sup> quadrant.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 28.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 29.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 30.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 31.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 32.svg|400px]]
Here is a similar sequence of rotations to the one we used for sine. This time compare the ''x'' coordinate of the point of rotation with the height of the point as it traces along the horizontal.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 33.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 34.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 35.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 36.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 37.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 38.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 39.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 40.svg|500px]]
The graph of ''y'' = cos(''x'') has a period of 2π. Just like sin(''x''), the ''x''-values never "escape" from the unit circle, so they stay between −1 and 1. The '''range''' of a cosine wave is also {−1 ≤ ''y'' ≤ 1}. And also just like the sine function, there is no restriction on the angle of rotation, so the '''domain''' of cos(''x'') is all reals.
==''y'' = tan(''x''), The Tangent Graph== The graph of the tangent ratio as a function of the angle of rotation presents a few complications. First of all, the domain is no longer all real angles. As you may remember there are some angles (90° and 270°, for example) for which the tangent is not defined. As we will see in this section, the range of tan(''x'') is actually all real numbers.
The measurement of each of the six trig functions can be found by using a single segment from the unit circle, however, the remaining functions are not as obvious as sine and cosine. The name of the tangent function comes from the tangent line, which is a line that is perpendicular to the radius of a circle at a point on the circle so that the line touches the circle at exactly one, and only one, point. So, to create the tangent segment, first we draw a tangent line perpendicular to the ''x'' axis.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 41.svg|450px]]
If we extend angle ''θ'' through the unit circle so that it intersects with the tangent line, the tangent function is defined as the length of the red segment.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 42.svg|450px]]
The dashed segment is 1 because it is the radius of the unit circle. Recall that the tangent of ''θ'' is <math>\tfrac{y}{x}</math>, so we can verify that this segment is indeed the tangent by using similar triangles.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 43.svg|500px]]
:<math>\tan(\theta) = \frac{y}{x} = \frac{t}{1} = t</math>
:<math>\tan(\theta) = t\,\!</math>
So, as we increase the angle of rotation, think about how this segment changes. When the angle is 0, the segment has no length. As we begin to rotate through the first quadrant, it will increase, very slowly at first.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 44.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 45.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 46.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 47.svg|400px]]
But, you can see very soon that the value increases past one. As the angle gets closer to 90°, the segment will need to stretch quite high in order to intersect the extension of the angle and it will grow at a faster and faster rate.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 48.svg|250px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 49.svg|300px]]
As we get ''very'' close to the ''y''axis that the segment gets infinitely large, until when the angle really hits 90°, at which point the extension of the angle and the tangent line will actually be parallel and therefore never meet!
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 50.svg|400px]]
This means there is no definition for the length of the tangent segment, or as it may be helpful to think of it, the tangent segment is ''infinitely large''.
Before continuing, let's take a look at this portion of the graph through the first quadrant. The tangent starts at 0, for a 0° angle, then increases slowly at first. That increase gets much steeper and as we approach a 90° rotation.
Again, just a small break in the ''x'' axis on these graphs will make it more clear that these two concepts to note lie side-by-side on the same coordinate grid.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 51.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 52.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 53.svg|400px]]
In fact as we get infinitely close to 90°, the tangent value increases without bound, until when we actually reach 90°, at which point the tangent is undefined. A line that a graph gets infinitely close to without touching is called an asymptote. So the tangent function has an asymptote at 90°.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 54.svg|400px]]
As we rotate past 90°, now the intersection of the extension of the angle and the tangent line is actually below the ''x'' axis. This fits nicely with what we know about the tangent for a 2<sup>nd</sup> quadrant angle being negative. It will be first be very, very negative, but as the angle rotates, the segment gets shorter, reaches 0, then crosses back into the positive numbers as the angle enters the 3<sup>rd</sup> quadrant.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 55.svg|250px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 56.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 57.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 58.svg|250px]]
The segment will again get infinitely large as it approaches 270°. After being undefined at 270°, the angle crosses into the 4<sup>th</sup> quadrant and once again changes from being infinitely negative, to approaching zero as we complete a full rotation.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 59.svg|250px]]
So, this motion graphed over several rotations would look like this:
:[[File:Tan proportional.svg|550px]]
Notice that the ''x'' axis is measured in radians (not in terms of π). Our asymptotes occur every π radians, starting at <math>\tfrac{\pi}{2}</math>. The period of the graph is therefore π radians. The domain is all reals except for the "holes" at <math>\tfrac{\pi}{2}</math>, <math>\tfrac{3\pi}{2}</math>, −<math>\tfrac{\pi}{2}</math>, etc. and the range is all real numbers.
==The Three Reciprocal Functions: cot(''x''), csc(''x''), and sec(''x'')== ===Cotangent=== Cotangent is the reciprocal of tangent, so it makes sense to generate the circular function for cotangent by drawing the tangent line at a point on the ''y'' axis and extending the angle, instead of the ''x'' axis.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 60.svg|400px]]
We can verify that this is the case again by using similar triangles. Because the purported cotangent segment is parallel to the base of the yellow triangle, then angle ''θ'' is in the opposite corner and the triangles are indeed similar, even though their positions are reversed.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 61.svg|500px]]
So,
:<math>\cot(\theta) = \frac{x}{y} = \frac{t}{1} = t</math>
:<math>\cot(\theta) = t\,\!</math>
Now that we have established the cotangent segment, think about how this segment changes as we rotate around the coordinate grid starting at 0°. First of all, at 0° itself, the cotangent is undefined because the segment is parallel to the ray of the angle ''θ''. As we begin to increase the angle of rotation, the segment will be extremely large and begin to get smaller as we approach 90°, very quickly at first, but then slowing down as it gets closer to 0 length at 90°.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 62.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 63.svg|500px]]
After passing 90°, the segment will again start to lengthen, but this time it will be in the negative direction, increasing slowly at first, then getting infinitely large in the negative direction until 180°, at which point it is again undefined.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 64.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 65.svg|500px]]
After passing this point, the periodic behavior kicks in and the function now repeats the same sequence of values as we rotate from 180°, back to 360°.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 66.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 67.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 68.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 69.svg|500px]]
Tracing this motion on the graph over several rotations gives:
:[[File:Cotan proportional.svg|500px]]
Remember that cotangent and tangent are reciprocals of each other, so any point at which the tangent was equal to 0, the cotangent will be undefined and any point at which the tangent was undefined, the cotangent is equal to 0.
:[[File:Tan-cotan proportional.svg|500px]]
You might also notice that the graphs consistently intersect at 1 and −1. These are the angles that have 45° reference angles, which always have tangents and cotangents equal to 1 or −1. It makes sense that 1 and −1 are the only values for which a function and its reciprocal are the same. Keep this in mind as we look at cosecant and secant compared to their reciprocals of sine and cosine.
The cotangent function has a domain of all real angles except multiples of π {… − 2π. − π.0, π, 2π …} The range is all real numbers.
===Cosecant=== There are many ways possible to find the cosecant segment. One approach is to look at the right triangle formed by the cotangent segment and use the Pythagorean Theorem to generate the cosecant.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 70.svg|400px]]
:{| cellpadding="3" style="text-align:right;" | <math>a^2 + b^2 = c^2\,\!</math> |- | <math>1^2 + \left (\frac{x}{y}\right )^2 = c^2</math> |- | <math>\left (\frac{y}{y}\right)^2 + \left (\frac{x}{y}\right )^2 = c^2</math> |- | <math>\frac{y^2}{y^2} + \frac{x^2}{y^2} = c^2</math> |- | <math>\frac{y^2 + x^2}{y^2} = c^2</math> |}
From the original triangle in the unit circle, ''y''<sup>2</sup> + ''x''<sup>2</sup> = ''r''<sup>2</sup>
:{| cellpadding="3" style="text-align:right;" | <math>\frac{r^2}{y^2} = c^2</math> |- | <math>\left (\frac{r}{y} \right )^2 = c^2</math> |}
Since <math>\tfrac{r}{y}</math> is cosecant, then the cosecant must be the same as side ''c''.
Tracing the length of this segment, it is undefined at 0°, infinitely large for very small angles, decreasing to 1 at 90° and then increasing infinitely until it is undefined at 180°. The process repeats from 180° to 360°, however, the segment starts infinitely negative, increases to −1 at 270° before approaching an infinitely negative length.
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 71.svg|550px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 72.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 73.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 74.svg|500px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 75.svg|400px]]
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 76.svg|400px]]
The period of the function is therefore 2π with a domain of all real angles except multiples of π {… −2π, −π, 0, π, 2π …}. The range is all real numbers greater than 1 or less than −1.
The graph then would look as follows:
:[[File:Cosec proportional.svg|500px]]
Here is the graph of ''y'' = sin(''x'') as well:
:[[File:Sin-cosec proportional.svg|500px]]
Notice again the reciprocal relationships at 0 and the asymptotes. Also look at the intersection points of the graphs at 1 and −1. Many students are reminded of parabolas when they look at the half period of the cosecant graph. While they are similar in that they each have a local minimum or maximum and they begin and end in the same direction the comparisons end there and they shouldn't be referred to as parabolic. The mathematics that defines the values, and therefore shape, of the graph is completely different from the quadratic function of a parabola.
===Secant=== Much like the relationship between sine and cosine, secant and cosecant share many similarities. The segment used to generate ''y'' = sec(''x'') is shown below:
:[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Figure 77.svg|400px]]
You will be asked to demonstrate this in the exercises section. This segment is 1 unit for 0°, then grows through the first quadrant, and is undefined at 90°. It is infinitely negative shrinking down to −1 through the 2<sup>nd</sup> quadrant, before lengthening back towards infinite negativity and is undefined at 270°. Translating this motion to a graph of ''y'' = sec(''x'') gives us:
:[[File:Sec proportional.svg|500px]]
Comparing it with the cosine graph:
:[[File:Cos-sec proportional.svg|500px]]
The period is 2π, the range is the same as ''y'' = csc(''x'') {''y'' : ''y'' ≥ 1 or ''y'' ≤ −1}, and the domain is all real angles except multiples of <math>\tfrac{\pi}{2}</math> {… −<math>\tfrac{3\pi}{2}</math>, −<math>\tfrac{\pi}{2}</math>, <math>\tfrac{\pi}{2}</math>, <math>\tfrac{3\pi}{2}</math> …}.
==Lesson Summary== The six trigonometric functions defined by the ratios in a right triangle can be placed in the context of the coordinate grid by thinking of them in terms of a point (''x'', ''y'') rotating around a circle centered at the origin with a radius of one. This circle is called the '''unit circle'''. The sine of the angle of rotation is the ''y''−coordinate of the point, the cosine of the angle is the x coordinate, and the tangent is <math>\tfrac{y}{x}</math>. The values of the other three ratios; cotangent, cosecant, and secant can also be found in terms of their reciprocal relationships, but all of these values can be constructed geometrically as various segments around the angle of rotation on the unit circle. Instead of finding isolated values, we can look at each ratio as a '''function''' of the angle of rotation. These are called '''circular functions'''. Here are the domains and ranges of the six circular trigonometric functions.
:{| class="wikitable" |+ Table 2.3 ! scope="col" | Function ! scope="col" | Domain ! scope="col" | Range |- | sin(''x'') || all reals || {''y'' : −1 ≤ ''y'' ≤ 1} |- | cos(''x'') || all reals || {''y'' : −1 ≤ ''y'' ≤ 1} |- | tan(''x'') || {''x'' : ''x'' ≠ ''n'' · <math>\tfrac{\pi}{2}</math>, where ''n'' is any odd integer} || all reals |- | csc(''x'') || {''x'' : ''x'' ≠ ''n''π, where ''n'' is any integer} || {''y'' : ''y'' > 1 or ''y'' < −1} |- | sec(''x'') || {''x'' : ''x'' ≠ ''n'' · <math>\tfrac{\pi}{2}</math>, where ''n'' is any odd integer} || {''y'' : ''y'' > 1 or ''y'' < −1} |- | cot(''x'') || {''x'' : ''x'' ≠ ''n'' · <math>\tfrac{\pi}{2}</math>, where ''n'' is any odd integer} || all reals |}
==Review Questions== # Show that side A in this drawing is equal to sec(''θ'').<br />[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Question 1.svg|400px]] # In Chapter 1, you learned that tan<sup>2</sup>(''θ'') + 1 = sec<sup>2</sup>(''θ''). Use the drawing and results from question 1 to demonstrate this identity. # This diagram shows a unit circle with all the angles that have reference angles of 30°, 45°, and 60°, as well as the quadrant angles. Label the coordinates of all points on the unit circle. On the smallest circle, label the angles in degrees, and on the middle circle, label the angles in radians.<br />[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Question 3.svg|500px]] # Draw and label the line segments in the following drawing that represent the six trigonometric functions (sine, cosine, tangent, cosecant, secant, cotangent).<br />[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Question 4.svg|400px]] # Which of the following shows functions that are both increasing as ''x'' increases from 0 to <math>\tfrac{\pi}{2}</math>? #:(a) sin(''x'') and cos(''x'') #:(b) tan(''x'') and csc(''x'') #:(c) sec(''x'') and cot(''x'') #:(d) csc(''x'') and sec(''x'') # Which of the following statements are true as ''x'' increases from <math>\tfrac{3\pi}{2}</math> to 2π? #:(a) cos(''x'') approaches 0 #:(b) tan(''x'') gets infinitely large #:(c) cos(''x'') < sin(''x'') #:(d) cot(''x'') gets infinitely small
==Review Answers== # Use similar triangles:<br />[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Answer 1a.svg|400px]]<br />[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Answer 1b.svg|400px]]<br />So:<br /><table cellpadding="3"><tr><td style="text-align:right;"><math>\frac{x}{1} =</math></td><td><math>\frac{1}{A}</math></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;"><math>Ax =\,\!</math></td><td><math>1\,\!</math></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;"><math>A =\,\!</math></td><td><math>\frac{1}{x}</math></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;"><math>\cos(\theta) =\,\!</math></td><td><math>x\,\!</math></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;"><math>\frac{1}{\cos(\theta)} =</math></td><td><math>\frac{1}{x}</math></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;"><math>\frac{1}{\cos(\theta)} =</math></td><td><math>\sec(\theta) = \frac{1}{x}</math></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;"><math>\therefore \sec(\theta) =\,\!</math></td><td><math>A\,\!</math></td></tr></table> # <br />[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Answer 2.svg|400px]]<br />Using the Pythagorean Theorem then, tan<sup>2</sup>(''θ'') + 1 = sec<sup>2</sup>(''θ''). # <br />[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Answer 3.svg|500px]] # <br />[[File:Circular Functions of Real Numbers Answer 4.svg|500px]] # b # d
{{chapnav|Applications of Radian Measure|Linear and Angular Velocity}}

== Referencing table elements ==
The [[/box/]] brackets can be used as an [[/alternative syntax/]] for referencing table [[/element/]]s:
print (student["age"]) -- equivalent to: print (student.age)
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: ManuelGR moved page [[Ada Programming/Input Output/Stream Tutorial/Example]] to [[Ada Programming/Libraries/Ada.Streams/Example]]: Moved as parent. Rationale: Following the convention used in other pages and winning some links to the parent page that w...
revision.text:
{{Ada/Navigation}} __TOC__ This page gives a (fairly complex) example of usage of class-wide stream related attributes {{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Read}}, {{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Write}}, {{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Input}}, and {{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Output}}. == The problem == The problem we will consider is the following: suppose that two hosts communicate over a TCP connection, exchanging information about vehicles. Each vehicle is characterized by its type (a car, a truck, a bicycle, and so on), its maximum speed (in km/h, represented by an integer number) and a set of further parameters that depend on the vehicle type. For example, a car could have a parameter "number of passengers," while a truck could have a parameter "maximum load" (an integer number of kg). For the sake of simplicity we will suppose that every parameter is represented by an integer number. The protocol used to communicate vehicle data over the wire is text-based and it is as follows * The first octet is a character that denotes the vehicle type. For example {{Ada/ch|c}} is for "car," {{Ada/ch|t}} is for "truck," {{Ada/ch|b}} is for "bicycle." * Next it comes the vehicle speed, represented as an integer number encoded as "<len> i <value>" where ** <value> is the speed value, expressed as a number in base 10 with <len> digits ** <len> is the length of the <value> field, expressed as a number in base 10. This field can have trailing spaces
For example, the integer 256 would be encoded as "3i256". * The speed value is followed by the list of vehicle-specific parameter, encoded with the same format of the speed field. We would like to use the features of Ada streams to read and write vehicle information from and to any "medium" (e.g., a network link, a file, a buffer in memory) and we would like to use the object-oriented features of Ada in order to simplify the introduction of a new type of vehicle. == The solution == This is a sketch of the proposed solution * We will create a hierarchy of objects to represent the vehicle types. More precisely, we will represent each vehicle as a descendant of an abstract type (Abstract_Vehicle) * Reading from a stream will be done via function Abstract_Vehicle'{{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Input}} that will work as follows *# it reads the first octet (by using Character'{{Ada/at|Read}}) and uses it to determine the type of vehicle *# it creates the object corresponding to the required vehicle type *# it calls Abstract_Vehicle'{{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Read}} by giving to it the newly created object in order to read it from the stream * Writing to a stream will be done via procedure Abstract_Vehicle'{{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Output}} that will work as follows *# it checks the object tag and uses it to determine the first character to be written to the stream *# it writes the first character to the stream by using Character'{{Ada/at|Write}} *# it calls Abstract_Vehicle'{{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Write}} to write the object description to the stream * We will derive a new type Int from Integer and we will define for it new procedures Int'{{Ada/at|Read}} and Int'{{Ada/at|Write}} that will read and write variables of type Int encoded in the format "<len> i <value>" described above * In order to allow for the introduction of new vehicle types (maybe by dynamically loading a library at runtime), at the step 2 of the Abstract_Vehicle'{{Ada/at|Class}}'{{Ada/at|Input}} function described we cannot use a {{Ada/kw|case}} on the character read in order to determine the type of the object to be created. We will instead use the generic dispatching constructor provided by Ada (see {{Ada/RM2|3|9|Tagged Types and Type Extensions|par=1/2}}). * Since the generic dispatching constructor requires the tag of the object to be created, we must be able to determine the tag that corresponds to a given character. We will achieve this by keeping an array of {{Ada/package|Ada|Tags}}.Tag indexed by character. A package defining a new vehicle will "register" itself in the initialization part of the package (that is, the sequence of statements that follows the {{Ada/kw|begin}} in the package body, see {{Ada/RM2|7|2|Package Bodies}}) by writing the tag of the defined vehicle in the suitable position of that array. == Implementation == === Streamable types === The first package that we are going to analyze is a package that defines a new integer type in order to assign to it attributes {{Ada/at|Read}} and {{Ada/at|Write}} that serialize integer values according to the format described above. The package specs are quite simple {{Ada/kw|with}} {{Ada/package|Ada.Streams}}; {{Ada/kw|package}} Streamable_Types {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|use}} {{Ada/package|Ada}}; {{Ada/kw|type}} Int {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|new}} Integer; {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Print (Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} {{Ada/package|Streams}}.Root_Stream_Type'{{Ada/at|Class}}; Item : Int); {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Parse (Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} {{Ada/package|Streams}}.Root_Stream_Type'{{Ada/at|Class}}; Item : {{Ada/kw|out}} Int); {{Ada/kw|for}} Int'{{Ada/at|Read}} {{Ada/kw|use}} Parse; {{Ada/kw|for}} Int'{{Ada/at|Write}} {{Ada/kw|use}} Print; Parsing_Error : {{Ada/kw|exception}}; {{Ada/kw|end}} Streamable_Types; The new type is Int and the procedure assigned to attributes {{Ada/at|Read}} and {{Ada/at|Write}} are, respectively, Parse and Read. Also the body is quite simple {{Ada/kw|with}} {{Ada/package|Ada.Strings.Fixed}}; {{Ada/kw|package}} {{Ada/kw|body}} Streamable_Types {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|use}} Streams; {{Ada/--|---------}} {{Ada/--| Print --}} {{Ada/--|---------}} {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Print (Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Root_Stream_Type'Class; Item : Int) {{Ada/kw|is}} Value : String := Strings.Fixed.Trim (Int'Image (Item), Strings.Left); Len : String := Integer'Image (Value'Length); Complete : String := Len & 'i' & Value; Buffer : Stream_Element_Array (Stream_Element_Offset (Complete'First) .. Stream_Element_Offset (Complete'Last)); {{Ada/kw|begin}} {{Ada/kw|for}} I {{Ada/kw|in}} Buffer'Range {{Ada/kw|loop}} Buffer (I) := Stream_Element (Character'Pos (Complete (Integer (I)))); {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|loop}}; Stream.Write (Buffer); {{Ada/kw|end}} Print; ----------- -- Parse -- ----------- {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Parse (Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Root_Stream_Type'Class; Item : {{Ada/kw|out}} Int) {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/--|Variables needed to read from Stream.}} Buffer : Stream_Element_Array (1 .. 1); Last : Stream_Element_Offset; {{Ada/--|Convenient constants}} Zero : {{Ada/kw|constant}} Stream_Element := Stream_Element (Character'Pos ('0')); Nine : {{Ada/kw|constant}} Stream_Element := Stream_Element (Character'Pos ('9')); Space : {{Ada/kw|constant}} Stream_Element := Stream_Element (Character'Pos (' ')); {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Skip_Spaces {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|begin}} {{Ada/kw|loop}} Stream.Read (Buffer, Last); {{Ada/kw|exit}} {{Ada/kw|when}} Buffer (1) /= Space; {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|loop}}; {{Ada/kw|end}} Skip_Spaces; {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Read_Length (Len : {{Ada/kw|out}} Integer) {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|begin}} {{Ada/kw|if}} {{Ada/kw|not}} (Buffer (1) {{Ada/kw|in}} Zero .. Nine) {{Ada/kw|then}} {{Ada/kw|raise}} Parsing_Error; {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|if}}; Len := 0; {{Ada/kw|loop}} Len := Len * 10 + Integer (Buffer (1) - Zero); Stream.Read (Buffer, Last); {{Ada/kw|exit}} {{Ada/kw|when}} {{Ada/kw|not}} (Buffer (1) in Zero .. Nine); {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|loop}}; {{Ada/kw|end}} Read_Length; {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Read_Value (Item : {{Ada/kw|out}} Int; Len : {{Ada/kw|in}} Integer) {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|begin}} Item := 0; {{Ada/kw|for}} I {{Ada/kw|in}} 1 .. Len {{Ada/kw|loop}} Stream.Read (Buffer, Last); {{Ada/kw|if}} {{Ada/kw|not}} (Buffer (1) {{Ada/kw|in}} Zero .. Nine) {{Ada/kw|then}} {{Ada/kw|raise}} Parsing_Error; {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|if}}; Item := 10 * Item + Int (Buffer (1) - Zero); {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|loop}}; {{Ada/kw|end}} Read_Value; Len : Integer := 0; {{Ada/kw|begin}} Skip_Spaces; Read_Length (Len); {{Ada/kw|if}} Character'Val (Integer (Buffer (1))) /= 'i' {{Ada/kw|then}} {{Ada/kw|raise}} Parsing_Error; {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|if}}; Read_Value(Item, Len); {{Ada/kw|end}} Parse; {{Ada/kw|end}} Streamable_Types; The body of Streamable_Types should not require any special comment. Note how the access to the stream is done by dispatching through the primitive procedures Read and Write, allowing the package above to work with any type of stream. === Abstract Vehicles === The second package we are going to analyze is Vehicles that define an abstract tagged type Abstract_Vehicle that represents the "least common denominator" of all the possible vehicles. {{Ada/kw|with}} Ada.Streams; {{Ada/kw|with}} Ada.Tags; {{Ada/kw|with}} Streamable_Types; {{Ada/kw|package}} Vehicles {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|type}} Abstract_Vehicle {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|abstract}} {{Ada/kw|tagged}} {{Ada/kw|private}}; {{Ada/kw|function}} Input_Vehicle (Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Ada.Streams.Root_Stream_Type'Class) {{Ada/kw|return}} Abstract_Vehicle'Class; {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Output_Vehicle (Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Ada.Streams.Root_Stream_Type'Class; Item : Abstract_Vehicle'Class); {{Ada/kw|for}} Abstract_Vehicle'Class'Input {{Ada/kw|use}} Input_Vehicle; {{Ada/kw|for}} Abstract_Vehicle'Class'Output {{Ada/kw|use}} Output_Vehicle; {{Ada/--|"Empty" type. The Generic_Dispatching_Constructor expects}} {{Ada/--|as parameter the type of the parameter of the constructor.}} {{Ada/--|In this case no parameter is needed, so we define this}} {{Ada/--|"placeholder type"}} {{Ada/kw|type}} Parameter_Record {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|record}}; {{Ada/--|Abstract constructor to be overriden by non-abstract}} {{Ada/--|derived types. It is needed by Generic_Dispatching_Constructor}} {{Ada/kw|function}} Constructor (Name : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Parameter_Record) {{Ada/kw|return}} Abstract_Vehicle {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|abstract}}; {{Ada/kw|private}} {{Ada/--|This procedure must be called by the packages that derive}} {{Ada/--|non-abstract type from Abstract_Vehicle in order to associate}} {{Ada/--|the vehicle "name" with the tag of the corresponding object}} {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Register_Name (Name : Character; Object_Tag : Ada.Tags.Tag); {{Ada/kw|type}} Kmh {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|new}} Streamable_Types.Int; {{Ada/kw|type}} Kg {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|new}} Streamable_Types.Int; {{Ada/--|Data shared by all the vehicles}} {{Ada/kw|type}} Abstract_Vehicle {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|abstract}} {{Ada/kw|tagged}} {{Ada/kw|record}} Speed : Kmh; Weight : Kg; {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|record}}; {{Ada/kw|end}} Vehicles; This package defines * Function Input_Vehicle and procedure Output_Vehicle to be used, respectively, as class-wide input and output procedures * Abstract constructor "Constructor" that every non-abstract type derived by Vehicle must override. This constructor will be called by Generic_Dispatching_Constructor in the body. * Procedure Register_Name that associates a vehicle "name" (represented by a character in this simplified case) to the corresponding type (represented by its Tag). In the typical case this procedure will be called by the package that derives from Abstract_Vehicle in the body initialization part The body of the package is {{Ada/kw|with}} Ada.Tags.Generic_Dispatching_Constructor; {{Ada/kw|package}} body Vehicles {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/--|Array used to map vehicle "names" to Ada Tags}} Name_To_Tag : {{Ada/kw|array}} (Character) {{Ada/kw|of}} Ada.Tags.Tag := ({{Ada/kw|others}} => Ada.Tags.No_Tag); {{Ada/--|Used as class-wide 'Input function}} {{Ada/kw|function}} Input_Vehicle (Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Ada.Streams.Root_Stream_Type'Class) {{Ada/kw|return}} Abstract_Vehicle'Class {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|function}} Construct_Vehicle {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|new}} Ada.Tags.Generic_Dispatching_Constructor (T => Abstract_Vehicle, Parameters => Parameter_Record, Constructor => Constructor); Param : {{Ada/kw|aliased}} Parameter_Record; Name : Character; {{Ada/kw|use}} Ada.Tags; {{Ada/kw|begin}} {{Ada/--|Read the vehicle "name" from the stream}} Character'Read (Stream, Name); {{Ada/--|Check if the name was associated with a tag}} {{Ada/kw|if}} Name_To_Tag (Name) = Ada.Tags.No_Tag then {{Ada/kw|raise}} Constraint_Error; {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|if}}; {{Ada/--|Use the specialization of Generic_Dispatching_Constructor}} {{Ada/--|defined above to create an object of the correct type}} {{Ada/kw|declare}} Result : Abstract_Vehicle'Class := Construct_Vehicle (Name_To_Tag (Name), Param'{{Ada/kw|Access}}); {{Ada/kw|begin}} {{Ada/--|Now Result is an object of the type associated with}} {{Ada/--|Name. Call the class-wide Read to fill it with the data}} {{Ada/--|read from the stream.}} Abstract_Vehicle'Class'Read (Stream, Result); {{Ada/kw|return}} Result; {{Ada/kw|end}}; {{Ada/kw|end}} Input_Vehicle; {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Output_Vehicle (Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Ada.Streams.Root_Stream_Type'Class; Item : Abstract_Vehicle'Class) {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|use}} Ada.Tags; {{Ada/kw|begin}} {{Ada/--|The first thing to be written on Stream is the}} {{Ada/--|character that identifies the type of Item}} {{Ada/--|We determine it by simply looping over Name_To_Tag}} {{Ada/kw|for}} Name {{Ada/kw|in}} Name_To_Tag'Range {{Ada/kw|loop}} {{Ada/kw|if}} Name_To_Tag (Name) = Item'Tag {{Ada/kw|then}} {{Ada/--|Found! Write the character to the stream, then}} {{Ada/--|use the class-wide Write to finish writing the}} {{Ada/--|description of Item to the stream}} Character'Write (Stream, Name); Abstract_Vehicle'Class'Write (Stream, Item); {{Ada/--|We did our duty, we can go back}} {{Ada/kw|return}}; {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|if}}; {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|loop}}; {{Ada/--|Note: If we arrive here, we did not find the tag of}} {{Ada/--|Item in Name_To_Tag.}} {{Ada/kw|raise}} Constraint_Error; {{Ada/kw|end}} Output_Vehicle; {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Register_Name (Name : Character; Object_Tag : Ada.Tags.Tag) {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|begin}} Name_To_Tag (Name) := Object_Tag; {{Ada/kw|end}} Register_Name; {{Ada/kw|end}} Vehicles; Note the behavior of Input_Vehicle, the function that will play the role of class-wide input. # First it reads the character associated to the next vehicle in the stream by using the stream-related function Character'Read. # Successively it uses the character read to find the tags of the object to be created # It creates the object by calling the specialized version of Generic_Dispatching_Constructor # It "fills" the newly created object by calling the class-wide Read that will take care of calling the Read associated to the newly created object Procedure Output_Vehicle is much simpler than Input_Vehicle since it does not need to use the Generic_Dispatching_Constructor. Just note the call to Abstract_Vehicle'Class'Write that in turn will call the Write function associated to the actual type of Item. Finally, note that Abstract_Vehicle does not define the Read and Write attributes. Therefore, Ada will use their default implementation. For example, Abstract_Vehicle'Read will read the two Streamable_Types.Int value Speed and Weight by calling twice the procedure Streamable_Types.Int'Read. A similar remark apply to Abstract_Vehicle'Write. === Non-Abstract Vehicles === ==== Car ==== The first non-abstract type derived from Abstract_Vehicle that we consider represents a car. In order to make the example a bit more rich, Car will be derived from an intermediate abstract type representing an engine-based vehicle. All engine-based vehicles will have a field representing the power of the engine (still an integer value, for the sake of simplicity). The spec file is as follows {{Ada/kw|package}} Vehicles.Engine_Based {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|type}} Abstract_Engine_Based {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|abstract}} {{Ada/kw|new}} Abstract_Vehicle {{Ada/kw|with}} {{Ada/kw|private}}; {{Ada/kw|private}} {{Ada/kw|type}} Abstract_Engine_Based {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|abstract}} {{Ada/kw|new}} Abstract_Vehicle {{Ada/kw|with}} {{Ada/kw|record}} Power : Streamable_Types.Int; {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|record}}; {{Ada/kw|end}} Vehicles.Engine_Based; Note that also in this case we did not define any Read or Write procedure. Therefore, for example, Abstract_Engine_Based'Read will first call Streamable_Types.Int twice to read Speed and Weight (inherited from Abstract_Vehicle) from the stream, then it will call Streamable_Types.Int another time to read Power. Note also that Abstract_Engine_Based does not override the abstract function Constructor of Abstract_Vehicle. This is not necessary since Abstract_Engine_Based is abstract. The spec file of the package that defines the Car type is as follows {{Ada/kw|package}} Vehicles.Engine_Based.Auto {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|use}} Ada.Streams; {{Ada/kw|type}} Car {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|new}} Abstract_Engine_Based {{Ada/kw|with}} {{Ada/kw|private}}; {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Parse (Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Root_Stream_Type'Class; Item : {{Ada/kw|out}} Car); {{Ada/kw|for}} Car'Read {{Ada/kw|use}} Parse; {{Ada/kw|private}} {{Ada/kw|type}} Car {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|new}} Abstract_Engine_Based {{Ada/kw|with}} {{Ada/kw|record}} Cilinders : Streamable_Types.Int; {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|record}}; {{Ada/kw|overriding}} {{Ada/kw|function}} Constructor (Param : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Parameter_Record) {{Ada/kw|return}} Car; {{Ada/kw|end}} Vehicles.Engine_Based.Auto; No special remarks are needed about the spec file. Just note that Car defines a special Read procedure and that it overrides Construct, as required since Car is not abstract. {{Ada/kw|package}} {{Ada/kw|body}} Vehicles.Engine_Based.Auto {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Parse (Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Root_Stream_Type'Class; Item : {{Ada/kw|out}} Car) {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|begin}} Abstract_Engine_Based'Read (Stream, Abstract_Engine_Based (Item)); Streamable_Types.Int'Read (Stream, Item.Cilinders); {{Ada/kw|end}} Parse; {{Ada/kw|overriding}} {{Ada/kw|function}} Constructor (Param : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Parameter_Record) {{Ada/kw|return}} Car {{Ada/kw|is}} Result : Car; {{Ada/kw|pragma}} Warnings(Off, Result); {{Ada/kw|begin}} {{Ada/kw|return}} Result; {{Ada/kw|end}} Constructor; {{Ada/kw|begin}} Register_Name('c', Car'Tag); {{Ada/kw|end}} Vehicles.Engine_Based.Auto; The body of Vehicles.Engine_Based.Auto is quite simple too, just note that * Procedure Parse (used as Car'Read) first calls Abstract_Engine_Based'Read to "fill" the part inherited from Abstract_Engine_Based, then it calls Streamable_Types.Int'Read to read the number of cylinders. Incidentally, note that this is equivalent to the default behavior, so it was not really necessary to define Parse. We did it just to make an example. * Note the call to Register_Name in the body initialization part that associates the name 'c' with the tag of type Car (obtained via the attribute 'Tag). An interesting property of this solution is that the information about the "external name" 'c' of objects of type Car is knew only inside the package Vehicles.Engine_Based.Auto. ==== Bicycle ==== The spec file of Vehicles.Bicycles {{Ada/kw|with}} Ada.Streams; {{Ada/kw|package}} Vehicles.Bicycles {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|use}} ada.Streams; {{Ada/kw|type}} Bicycle {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|new}} Abstract_Vehicle {{Ada/kw|with}} {{Ada/kw|private}}; {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Parse (Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Root_Stream_Type'Class; Item : {{Ada/kw|out}} Bicycle); for Bicycle'Read {{Ada/kw|use}} Parse; {{Ada/kw|private}} {{Ada/kw|type}} Wheel_Count {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|new}} Streamable_Types.Int range 1 .. 3; {{Ada/kw|type}} Bicycle {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|new}} Abstract_Vehicle {{Ada/kw|with}} {{Ada/kw|record}} Wheels : Wheel_Count; {{Ada/kw|end}} {{Ada/kw|record}}; overriding {{Ada/kw|function}} Constructor (Name : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Parameter_Record) {{Ada/kw|return}} Bicycle; {{Ada/kw|end}} Vehicles.Bicycles; The body of Vehicles.Bicycles {{Ada/kw|package}} {{Ada/kw|body}} Vehicles.Bicycles {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|use}} Ada.Streams; {{Ada/kw|procedure}} Parse (Stream : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Root_Stream_Type'Class; Item : {{Ada/kw|out}} Bicycle) {{Ada/kw|is}} {{Ada/kw|begin}} Abstract_Vehicle'Read (Stream, Abstract_Vehicle (Item)); Wheel_Count'Read (Stream, Item.Wheels); {{Ada/kw|end}} Parse; overriding {{Ada/kw|function}} Constructor (Name : {{Ada/kw|not}} {{Ada/kw|null}} {{Ada/kw|access}} Parameter_Record) {{Ada/kw|return}} Bicycle {{Ada/kw|is}} Result : Bicycle; {{Ada/kw|pragma}} Warnings(Off, Result); {{Ada/kw|begin}} {{Ada/kw|return}} Result; {{Ada/kw|end}} Constructor; {{Ada/kw|begin}} Register_Name ('b', Bicycle'Tag); {{Ada/kw|end}} Vehicles.Bicycles; == See also == === Wikibook === * [[Ada Programming]] * [[Ada Programming/Object Orientation]] * [[Ada_Programming/Input_Output]] * [[Ada Programming/Libraries/Ada.Streams]] === Ada 2005 Reference Manual === * {{Ada/2005/RM2|3|9|Tagged Types and Type Extensions|par=1/2}} * {{Ada/2005/RM2|7|2|Package Bodies}} * {{Ada/2005/RM3|13|13|1|The Package Streams}} * {{Ada/2005/RM3|13|13|2|Stream-Oriented Attributes}} {{BookCat}}

== Length operator ==
The hash symbol acts as a unary [[/length operator/]].
=== Length of a string ===
When used against a [[/string/]], the [[/length operator/]] returns the number of [[/byte/]]s within the [[/string/]].
=== Length of a table ===
When used against a[[/table/]] that is not [[/sparse/]], the [[/length operator/]] returns the number of the last non [[/null/]] element in the [[/table/]]. For an [[/empty/]] table, a value of [[/zero/]] will be returned:
==== Sparse tables ====
Note that if a [[/table/]] contains [[/hole/]]s, the [[/length operator/]] considers the first [[/null/]] element to be the end of the [[/table/]], and will return the [[/element/]] number that immediately precedes the [[/null/]] element.
{{BookCat}}

== Execution Errors ==
When an execution error occurs in a lua script, execution returns to the [[../caller/]] programme for appropriate action to be taken.
== Explicit error generation ==
The [[../error/]] function can be used to generate an explicit error status.
== Error trap ==
The [[../pcall/]] function can be used as an error trap.
{{BookCat}}

The error function is used to generate an explicit error status.
{{BookCat}}

The pcall [[/function/]] can be used as an error trap.
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Fixed minor typo that I just spotted.

page.title: Basic Physics of Digital Radiography/The Applications

revision.comment: [[WB:REVERT|Reverted]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/203.206.116.43|203.206.116.43]] ([[User talk:203.206.116.43|talk]]) to last version by QuiteUnusual
revision.text:
[[File:Ivu_1.jpg|thumb|150px|A radiograph from an Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP) series.]]
A selection of clinical applications of Digital Radiography are described in this chapter. General Radiography, being one of the mainstays of Diagnostic Radiography, has changed from a film-based imaging process to one based on digital technologies. The impact of these changes in terms of radiation dose and image quality are discussed in this chapter. Specialised applications such as Mammography, Digital Subtraction Angiography, C-Arm Computed Tomography, Multi-Detector CT, Dual-Energy Radiography and Image Fusion are also considered.
== General Radiography ==
Digital image receptors have been increasingly applied in general radiography since the turn of the century. Early studies indicated its superior image quality relative to film/screen technology in skeletal radiography<ref><small>Hamers S, Freyschmidt J & Neitzel U, 2001. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11511898 Digital radiography with a large-scale electronic flat-panel detector vs. screen-film radiography: Observer preference in clinical skeletal diagnostics]. Eur Radiol, 11:1753-9.</small></ref><ref><small>Peer S, Neitzel U, Giacomuzzi SM, Pechlaner S, Künzel KH, Peer R, Gassner E, Steingruber I, Gaber O & Jaschke W, 2002. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12014869 Direct digital radiography versus storage phosphor radiography in the detection of wrist fractures]. Clin Radiol, 57:258-62.</small></ref>. On this basis, refinements of exposure technique have also occurred<ref><small>Uffmann M, Schaefer-Prokop C, Neitzel U, Weber M, Herold CJ & Prokop M, 2004. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15128995 Skeletal applications for flat-panel versus storage-phosphor radiography: Effect of exposure on detection of low-contrast details]. Radiology, 231:506-14.</small></ref><ref><small>Hamer OW, Völk M, Zorger N, Borisch I, Büttner R, Feuerbach S & Strotzer M, 2004. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15377940 Contrast-detail phantom study for x- ray spectrum optimization regarding chest radiography using a cesium iodide-amorphous silicon flat-panel detector]. Invest Radiol, 39:610-8.</small></ref><ref><small>Uffmann M, Neitzel U, Prokop M, Kabalan N, Weber M, Herold CJ & Schaefer-Prokop C, 2004. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15858104 Flat-panel-detector chest radiography: Effect of tube voltage on image quality]. Radiology, 235:642-50.</small></ref><ref><small>Hamer OW, Sirlin CB, Strotzer M, Borisch I, Zorger N, Feuerbach S & Völk M, 2005. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16192324 Chest radiography with a flat-panel detector: Image quality with dose reduction after copper filtration]. Radiology, 237:691-700.</small></ref>. Furthermore, dose comparisons with traditional radiography and various forms of Computed Radiography (CR) with direct and indirect Digital Radiography (DR) have been made<ref><small>Bacher K, Smeets P, Bonnarens K, De Hauwere A & Verstraete K, Thierens H, 2003. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/14500203 Dose reduction in patients undergoing chest imaging: Digital amorphous silicon flat-panel detector radiography versus conventional film-screen radiography and phosphor-based computed radiography]. Am J Roentgenol, 181:923-9</small></ref></small><ref><small>Völk M, Hamer OW, Feuerbach S & Strotzer M, 2004. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/14968260 Dose reduction in skeletal and chest radiography using a large-area flat- panel detector based on amorphous silicon and thallium-doped cesium iodide: Technical background, basic image quality parameters, and review of the literature]. Eur Radiol, 14:827-34.</small></ref><ref><small>Bacher K, Smeets P, Ver- eecken L, De Hauwere A, Duyck P, De Man R, Verstraete K & Thierens H, 2006. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16928923 Image quality and radiation dose on digital chest imaging: Comparison of amorphous silicon and amorphous selenium flat-panel systems]. Am J Roentgenol, 187:630-7.</small></ref>. In addition, the performance of digital image receptors for fluoroscopic applications has also been investigated<ref><small>Davies AG, Cowen AR, Kengyelics SM, Moore J & Sivananthan MU, 2007. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17115166 Do flat detector cardiac X-ray systems convey advantages over image-intensifier-based systems? Study comparing X-ray dose and image quality]. Eur Radiol, 17:1787-94.</small></ref>.
Results of these investigations have indicated significant advantages in favour of the digital technology. In general, the change in image receptors has been technically similar to the transition from film-based to [[W:Digital_camera|digital cameras]] in photography. However, work practice changes and capital cost are major considerations with the implementation of digital radiography<ref><small>Stadlbauer A, Salomonowitz E, Radlbauer R, Salomonowitz G & Lomoschitz F, 2010. A SWOT (Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities and Threats) analysis of current digital radiography systems for thorax- and skeletal diagnostics. [http://www.thieme.de/fz/gesqm.html Gesundheitsökonomie & Qualitätsmanagement], 15:199-207.</small></ref>.
Experience to the year 2010 has indicated that from a physics perspective<ref><small>Schaefer-Prokop C, Neitzel U, Venema HW, Uffmann M & Prokop M, 2008. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18431577 Digital chest radiography: An update on modern technology, dose containment and control of image quality]. Eur Radiol, 18:1818-30.</small></ref><ref><small>Schaefer-Prokop CM, De Boo DW, Uffmann M & Prokop M, 2009. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19695809 DR and CR: Recent advances in technology]. Eur J Radiol, 72:194-201.</small></ref>:
::*Standard CR plates provide no dose reduction relative to traditional 400-speed film/screen systems, ::*Dual-side read-out CR has a DQE about 40–50% higher than single-side read-out CR, ::*Stuctured phosphor CR has a DQE about 50% higher than dual-side read-out CR and approaches that of indirect DR, ::*Indirect DR receptors with structured phosphors have a DQE about twice that of direct DR receptors at spatial frequencies below 4 LP/mm, ::*Doses with indirect, structured phosphor DR are 30–50% lower than 400-speed film/screen systems, and ::*Dose savings are limited for highly attenuating regions of the body (e.g. retro-cardiac and infra-diaphragmatic areas of chest radiographs), but can exceed 50% in regions of high X-ray transparency (e.g. the lung fields).
From a practical perspective, convenience has been enhanced in the clinical application of these devices by the incorporation of [[W:Wi-Fi|Wi-Fi]] connectivity between the image receptor and the digital image processor. CR imaging cassettes, including read-out device, and DR cassettes of similar size to the traditional film/screen cassettes have also been developed. These can therefore be used without much change in the design of patient tables, upright Bucky stands and other radiographic apparatus.
The application of DR technologies has also led the development of new imaging techniques, such as [[W:Tomosynthesis#Tomosynthesis|Digital Tomosynthesis]] and Temporal Subtraction, and to new forms of digital image processing, e.g. rib suppression in chest radiography<ref><small>Veldkamp WJ, Kroft LJ & Geleijns J, 2009. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19577393 Dose and perceived image quality in chest radiography]. Eur J Radiol. 2009 Nov;72(2):209-17.</small></ref> and [[W:Computer-assisted_diagnosis|Computer-Assisted Diagnosis]] (CAD)<ref><small>McAdams HP, Samei E, Dobbins J 3rd, Tourassi GD & Ravin CE, 2006. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17114619 Recent advances in chest radiography]. Radiology. 2006 Dec;241(3):663-83.</small></ref>. These topics however are beyond the scope of our considerations here.
== Mammography ==
Mammography is a form of soft tissue imaging and the instrumentation used is designed specifically for imaging the female [[W:Breast|breast]]. Low X-ray energies are therefore required to exploit the [[Basic_Physics_of_Digital_Radiography/The_Patient#Photoelectric_Effect|Photoelectric Effect]] and thereby enhance the discrimination between different types of tissues. In addition, fine details such as microcalcifications also need to be resolved by the imaging system. Small focal spot XRTs and high resolution image receptors are therefore required. These specific requirements are considered in more detail below.
==== Mammography X-Ray Tubes ====
:An X-ray energy of ~20 keV is needed to generate adequate subject contrast between different tissues. Such an energy provides discrimination between [[W:Mammary_ductal_carcinoma|infiltrating duct carcinomas]] and [[W:Adipose_tissue|fat]], for example, although with little differentiation between fat and [[W:Fibrous_tissue|fibrous tissue]]<ref><small>Johns PC & Yaffe MJ, 1987. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3039542 X-ray characterisation of normal and neoplastic breast tissues]. Phys Med Biol, 32:675-95.</small></ref>.
[[File:moAnodeSpectra.jpg|thumb|320px|center|Fig. 7.22: X-ray energy spectra for (a) a Mo anode XRT, and (b) with the addition of 30 μm thickness of Mo filtration]]
:[[W:Molybdenum|Molybdenum]] (Mo) can be used instead of tungsten as the anode material in the [[Basic_Physics_of_Digital_Radiography/The_Source#X-Ray_Tube|X-ray tube]] (XRT). The Mo energy spectrum consists of K-Characteristic lines between 17 and 19 keV and a Bremsstrahlung continuum - see Figure 7.22. The Bremsstrahlung can be attenuated using an added Mo filter which preferentially eliminates the low energy radiation, that would otherwise be completely absorbed by the tissues and contribute little to image formation, as well as higher energy X-rays which would otherwise degrade subject contrast. This is an example of the application of [[Basic_Physics_of_Digital_Radiography/The_Source#Beam_Filtration|K-edge filtration]].
:[[W:|Rhodium]] (Rh) can also be used for both the anode and the filter materials. Rh has a K-edge at 23.2 keV, which is a little above that of Mo, and this can offer advantages for imaging the thicker, denser breast at a lower absorbed dose than with the Mo anodes. This results because of the superior penetration of the Rh K-shell characteristic X-rays. Other anode/filter combinations, such as Mo/Rh, W/Ag and W/Rh have also been used.
:Most X-ray tubes used for contact mammography have small focal spots (e.g. 0.3 mm) which are less than half the size used in general radiography. Such small focal spots are needed to image fine detail such as [[W:Microcalcification|microcalcifications]], that may be no larger than 100 μm. The resultant heating of the XRT anode can limit tube currents to a maximum of no more than ~100 mA at 25 kV so that long exposure times up to 3 seconds or more are needed to compensate. Patient movement therefore needs to be suppressed during the exposure.
:Mammography XRTs are generally constructed with a metal envelope, instead of the usual glass, with a thin [[W:Beryllium|beryllium]] (Be) exit port. This design has the advantage of suppressing [[Basic_Physics_of_Digital_Radiography/The_Source#Heel_Effect|extra-focal radiation]]. In addition, the tube can be constructed so that the anode-cathode axis is offset to achieve the small focal spot size - see Figure 7.23.
:Furthermore, it has been found that the focal spot should be located on a line, perpendicular to the image receptor, which contains the chest wall margin. Equally importantly, the collimator should also be adjusted to ensure that the X-ray beam intercepts the image receptor on that margin.
[[File:mammoXRT.jpg|thumb|320px|center|Fig. 7.23: A mammographic XRT with collimation and breast support.]]
==== Mammography Image Receptors ====
:An ideal imaging system for mammography would require a [[Basic_Physics_of_Digital_Radiography/The_Image#Spatial_Resolution|limiting spatial resolution]] of ~20 LP/mm or more and a dynamic range of at least 5,000:1, achieved with minimal radiation dose to the patient. A matrix size of at least 9,600x7,200 pixels, each with a minimum of 12 bits depth, would be needed to achieve the required spatial resolution within a typical field of view of 18x24 cm. The computer storage required for one image would therefore be 132 Mbytes. Even at a limiting resolution of 10 LP/mm, 33 Mbytes of storage would still be needed for a single digital image.
:The major problem with applying CR technology to mammography is its spatial resolution, which is limited to less than ~5 LP/mm, with the sampling rate of 10 pixels/mm as generally used. The anticipated loss of resolution may not be a serious problem, however, because of the superior contrast and dynamic range available for post-acquisition digital image processing. Reducing the diameter of the stimulating laser beam, use of a thinner phosphor layer and dual-sided read-out CR plates<ref><small>Rivetti S, Canossi B, Battista R, Lanconelli N, Vetruccio E, Danielli C, Borasi G & Torricelli P, 2009. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19922306 Physical and clinical comparison between a screen-film system and a dual-side reading mammography-dedicated computed radiography system]. Acta Radiol, 50:1109-18.</small></ref> are three approaches which can be used to address this issue.
:Both direct and indirect DR receptors can be used for Digital Mammography. Here, the manufacturing technology limits pixel size to about 70-100 μm for image sizes up to 3,328x4,096 pixels of area up to 24x29 cm. Once again, it is assumed that the lack of spatial resolution is compensated by the broad dynamic range of the image receptor as well as the spatial frequency and contrast enhancement capabilities of digital image processing.
:Another technique for obtaining a digital image involves coupling a conventional phosphor screen to a [[W:Charge-coupled_device|Charge Coupled Device]] (CCD) using lenses or fibre optic coupling. The CCD matrix can be just 1,024x1,024 pixels in small field applications and systems have demonstrated limiting spatial resolutions of ~10 LP/mm. Larger fields of view can be achieved using an array of CCDs - see Figure 7.24, panel (a). When individual pixels are of size 40 μm and a detector area of 18x24 cm, an image matrix of 4,800x6,400 pixels results, which can provide a spatial resolution of 12.5 LP/mm. Broader area receptors have also found application in General Radiography, and digital implementation of Multiple Beam Equalization Radiography ('''AMBER''') has been investigated<ref><small>Liu X, Shaw CC, Lai CJ, Wang T, 2011. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21361171 Comparison of scatter rejection and low-contrast performance of scan equalization digital radiography (SEDR), slot-scan digital radiography, and full-field digital radiography systems for chest phantom imaging]. Med Phys, 38:23-33.</small></ref>.
:[[File:mammoCCD.jpg|thumb|center|320px|Fig. 7.24: (a) A large phosphor screen coupled to several CCDs using fibre optic tapers; (b) A scanning-slot system where a narrow phosphor screen is coupled by the fibre optics to a few CCDs and the XRT/detector is scanned across the anatomy.]]
:Another alternative is to use a slot scanning arrangement - see Figure 7.24, panel (b). Here, X-rays transmitted through the compressed breast produce light in a strip of CsI:Tl phosphor and this light is collected by the fibre optics and conveyed to the CCD arrays. Some features of this design are:
::*the X-ray beam is collimated to a fan of narrow width (e.g. 22 x 1 cm), giving high level of scatter rejection, ::*the phosphor is coupled to a number of discrete CCD arrays abutted together to form a linear array. Each CCD array has 2,048x400 pixels of sufficiently small size that the system achieves a spatial resolution of 10 LP/mm or greater, ::*the image is acquired line by line by scanning the fan-shaped X-ray beam across the breast at a constant speed - see Figure 7.25. This form of image acquisition is analogous to the '''Scanned Projection Radiography''' image, also called ''Scout View'', used in Computed Tomography (CT) scanning, ::*Image acquisition time is 5 seconds, and ::*Since the X-ray field-of-view and phosphor detector are relatively small, scatter does not represent a serious problem and grids do not need to be used - which represents a potential dose saving for patients.
[[File:mammoScanningSlot.jpg|thumb|320px|center|Fig. 7.25: Illustration of scanned-slot digital mammography.]]
:One of the disadvantages of the scanning slot approach is the necessity for long exposure times which increases the load on the X-ray tube. This can be addressed using a tungsten anode XRT, which has a substantially greater efficiency for X-ray production and heat dissipation than a tube with a molybdenum anode. The tube can operated between 20 and 45 kV with a choice of Al, Mo or Rh filters. This may seem counterproductive given the [[Basic_Physics_of_Digital_Radiography/The_Applications#Mammography_X-Ray_Tubes|earlier discussion]] on the importance of using low kV in order to achieve high subject contrast. However, the detector has a dynamic range of 5,000:1 so that, while subject contrast is reduced, high image contrast can nevertheless be achieved.
:Scanning systems have also been developed based on photon counting detectors, e.g. crystalline silicon X-ray detectors and multichannel gaseous ionisation chambers. These have the advantage that they detect each X-ray photon absorption event in the detector, instead of integrating the image signal generated by multiple photons as occurs with conventional image receptors. Image noise can therefore be suppressed using thresholding techniques.
:The performance of five imaging systems for Digital Mammography is compared in Lazzari et al. (2007)<ref><small>Lazzari B, Belli G, Gori C & Rosselli Del Turco M, 2007. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17821981 Physical characteristics of five clinical systems for digital mammography]. Med Phys. 2007 Jul;34(7):2730-43.</small></ref>. A higher DQE for direct over indirect DR image receptors was found, and both were superior to a scanning-slot system. Further, the application of digital tomosynthesis to mammography, called '''Digital Breast Tomosynthesis''' (DBT), has been investigated<ref><small>Gennaro G, Toledano A, di Maggio C, Baldan E, Bezzon E, La Grassa M, Pescarini L, Polico I, Proietti A, Toffoli A & Muzzio PC. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20033175 Digital breast tomosynthesis versus digital mammography: A clinical performance study]. Eur Radiol, 20:1545-53.</small></ref>.
==== Mammography AEC ====
:Unlike the AEC in conventional radiography, the controlling detector cannot be placed in front of a CR imaging cassette because it would attenuate the X-ray beam too severely and cast its own X-ray shadow. The shadow is significant especially at the low X-ray energies used in mammography. However, when it is placed behind the cassette, the amount of X-ray flux reaching the controlling detector is strongly influenced by absorption in the image receptor, which in itself is strongly dependent on the energy of the X-ray photons emerging from the patient. The net result is that conventional AEC devices compensate very poorly for changes in breast type, thickness and kilo-voltage. These problems can be overcome,however, using microprocessor-controlled HV generator switching. The AEC detector measures the instantaneous dose-rate and, based on the selected kV and/or the measured breast thickness, terminates the exposure at the appropriate time using a look-up table (LUT). There can be a separate LUT set up for each operational mode, e.g. contact mammography with a grid, contact without a grid and magnified imaging.
:The function of an AEC can be expanded using the '''Auto-kV''' mode of operation. The control system quickly decides, within ~10-30 ms of exposure initiation, whether the selected kV is going to allow the desired image quality to be achieved in a sufficiently short time. If not, the kV can be increased appropriately to ensure that the exposure time limit, dictated by the [[Basic_Physics_of_Digital_Radiography/The_Source#TLC|tube loading]], is not exceeded.
:Direct radiography (DR) systems can use the image receptor itself as the AEC sensor<ref><small>Gennaro G, Golinelli P, Bellan E, Colombo P, D'Ercole L, Di Nallo A, Gallo L, Giordano C, Meliadò G, Morri B, Nassivera E, Oberhofer N, Origgi D, Paolucci M, Paruccini N, Piergentili M, Rizzi E & Rossi R, 2008. [http://www.springerlink.com/content/7532243132t7h347/ Automatic Exposure Control in Digital Mammography: Contrast-to-Noise Ratio Versus Average Glandular Dose]. Lecture Notes in Computer Science, 5116: 711-5.</small></ref>.
==== Mammography Scatter Reduction ====
:Compression of the breast tissues is critical for:
::*[[Basic_Physics_of_Digital_Radiography/The_Patient#Scatter_Reduction|reducing scattered radiation]] that would otherwise reduce subject contrast, ::*improving contrast by decreasing the amount of [[Basic_Physics_of_Digital_Radiography/The_Source#Beam_Filtration|beam hardening]] that occurs as the X-ray beam passes through the tissues, ::*immobilising the breast, ::*locating breast structure closer to the imaging plane, ::*producing a more uniform breast thickness, and ::*reducing absorbed dose through the use of reduced exposure times.
:Compression pads can be made from a thin plate of polycarbonate or perspex. Their design is such that creeping of breast tissue up the chest wall is prevented when the breast is being compressed.
:In addition, grids are used to further reduce scattered radiation and improve subject contrast. They are typically moving grids made with a carbon fibre interspace, although other designs are also in use, e.g. honeycomb grids with copper as the attenuator and air as the interspace material. [[Basic_Physics_of_Digital_Radiography/The_Patient#BuckyF|Bucky Factors]] are typically 2-2.5 for grid ratios of 4:1 or 5:1.
:Adequate subject contrast is generally achieved with kilo-voltages less than 28 kV, and even lower (e.g. 23 kV) for thinner breast thicknesses.
==== Magnification Mammography ====
[[File:mammoLoRad.jpg|thumb|Fig. 7.26: Photograph of a mammography system.]]
:[[Basic_Physics_of_Digital_Radiography/The_Patient#Imaging_Geometry|Magnification]] mammography with m = 1.5-2.0 is widely used in follow-up studies where lesion localization techniques might be necessary. There are several technical advantages associated with magnification radiography, which include:
::*improved spatial resolution of the recording system, ::*reduction of image noise arising from the structural components of the image receptor, and ::*reduction of scatter because of the air gap (e.g. 15-30 cm), particularly in coned down magnification studies.
:Note that these advantages are achieved at the expense of increased radiation dose to the part of the breast in the primary beam because of a consequent requirement to position the breast closer to the X-ray tube in many clinical systems - see Figure 7.26, for example.
:In addition, a focal spot as small as 0.1 mm is typically used for magnification mammography. Problems with long exposure times are significant in situations where the maximum tube current is only 15-25 mA. A compromise between patient movement and subject contrast can be reached by increasing the kilo-voltage to 30-32 kV so as to keep the exposure time within reasonable bounds. However, it should be appreciated that magnification imaging is a higher dose technique which is caused by the proximity of the breast to the focal spot, so that an increase in the skin dose by anything up to a factor of four results. Although this increase is partially offset by the fact that only a region of the breast is generally irradiated and a grid is not necessary for such views, the net result is an increase in absorbed dose by a factor of about two.
[[W:Stereotactic_biopsy|Stereotactic]] imaging can be used to assist core biopsy sampling using, for example, 14-[[W:Needle_gauge|gauge]] needles. Although attachments can be made to conventional mammography equipment for these procedures, superior ergonomics is provided by prone systems with the breast to be biopsied placed in a pendant position through a hole in the patient couch. The XRT, compression pad, imaging receptor and biopsy gun are all mounted below the table whose height can be adjusted to allow sufficient space for positioning the needle. The biopsy gun is typically mounted on a [[W:Vernier_scale|Vernier]] driven table that allows accurate positioning of the needle during the biopsy procedure. Images of the localized region containing the suspicious lesion in the compressed breast are generally taken with the XRT at two different locations, usually ±15° to a line perpendicular to the image plane, so to provide co-ordinate information for the computer-controlled advance of the biopsy needle.
Finally, it should be noted that [[W:Breast_cancer_screening|mammography screening]] was conducted annually in a cohort of 100,000 women from ages 40 to 55 years and biennially until 74 years at a dose of 3.7 mGy per breast examination<ref><small>Yaffe MJ & Mainprize JG, 2011. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21081671 Risk of radiation-induced breast cancer from mammographic screening]. Radiology, 258:98-105.</small></ref>. It was predicted that these exposures would ultimately induce 86 breast cancers, 11 fatal, and that 10,670 woman-years would be saved because of early detection. The risk of radiation-induced breast cancer associated with routine mammographic screening of women over 40 is therefore considered to be extremely low, especially when compared with the anticipated benefits of screening, and, as a consequence, radiation risk should not deter women from mammographic screening.
== Digital Subtraction Angiography ==
[[W:Digital_subtraction_angiography|Digital Subtraction Angiography]] (DSA), as the name implies, involves an image subtraction technique - see Figure 7.1. As will be seen below, the technique involves more than simply applying a subtraction process in the digital image processor. In addition, it will be seen that the type of technology utilised, while based on the design of fluoroscopy systems, needs to incorporate a number of modifications unique to DSA. Before addressing the technology however, some basic physics needs to be introduced which will aid in putting the subsequent technology discussion into context.
[[File:dsaImages.jpg|thumb|480px|center|Fig. 7.1: Images from a DSA study: (a) Mask Image; (b) Live Image; (c) Mask-Live Image; (d) Live-Mask Image.]]
==== Basic DSA Physics ====
:The process of subtraction angiography, as illustrated simplistically in Figure 7.2, involves the subtraction of a post-opacification image (commonly called the '''Live''' image) from a pre-opacification image of the same region (commonly called the '''Mask''' image). When it is assumed that monoenergetic X-rays irradiate the patient and that no scattered radiation is generated, the radiation intensity, I<sub>2</sub>, for an appropriate point of the live image is related to the intensity, I<sub>1</sub>, for the same point of the mask image, by:
[[File:dsaIllustration.jpg|thumb|Fig. 7.2: Illustration of subtraction in angiography for a hypothetical blood vessel of thickness t<sub>c</sub>.]]
<center>I<sub>2</sub> = I<sub>1</sub> exp (-μ<sub>c</sub> ρ<sub>c</sub> t<sub>c</sub>)</center>
:where μ<sub>c</sub>, ρ<sub>c</sub> and t<sub>c</sub> are the [[Basic_Physics_of_Digital_Radiography/The_Basics#Attenuation_of_X-Rays|mass attenuation coefficient]], concentration and thickness, respectively, of the contrast medium. Thus, when I<sub>2</sub> is subtracted directly from I<sub>1</sub>, the subtracted image is given by:
<center>D = I<sub>1</sub> - I<sub>2</sub>.</center>
:Thus, <center>D = I<sub>1</sub> - I<sub>1</sub> exp(-μ<sub>c</sub> ρ<sub>c</sub> t<sub>c</sub>)</center>
:and, hence
<center>D = I<sub>1</sub> [1 - exp (-μ<sub>c</sub> ρ<sub>c</sub> t<sub>c</sub>)].</center>
:This equation indicates that the subtraction signal, D, contains information from the mask image I<sub>1</sub>, as well as from the live image. As a result, the density of opacified vessels in the subtraction image will contain artifacts which are dependent on the anatomical details which underlie and overlap the blood vessels within the patient. These artifacts result because of the exponential nature of radiation attenuation in matter. They may be reduced ideally by computing the natural logarithm of the transmitted intensities prior to subtraction. When this is done the subtraction image is now dependent on the contrast medium only - with no artifacts from surrounding anatomy, as follows:
<center>D<sub>log</sub> = ''ln'' I<sub>1</sub> - ''ln'' I<sub>2</sub>,</center>
:so that:
<center>D<sub>log</sub> = ''ln'' I<sub>1</sub> - ''ln'' I<sub>1</sub> + μ<sub>c</sub> ρ<sub>c</sub> t<sub>c</sub></center>
:and therefore,
<center>D<sub>log</sub> = μ<sub>c</sub> ρ<sub>c</sub> t<sub>c</sub>.</center>
:Many DSA systems utilise the above reasoning to logarithmically transform both the mask and the live images prior to subtraction. A second theoretical advantage of this logarithmic subtraction process is the generation of images which are not influenced by spatial non-uniformities of the imaging device. [[Basic_Physics_of_Digital_Radiography/The_Image_Receptor#XII-Video_Systems|X-ray image intensifiers]], for example, display significant spatial non-uniformities.
:A third theoretical advantage of logarithmic subtraction is the generation of images in which the image density is directly proportional to the projected thickness of the contrast medium, ρ<sub>c</sub>t<sub>c</sub>. This feature has given rise to the use of [[W:Densitometry|densitometric analysis]] of images so as to derive clinically-useful indices of function, e.g. percent [[W:Stenosis|stenosis]] and [[W:Ejection_fraction|left ventricular ejection fraction]]. However, it is important to note that the above reasoning is based on a number of simplifying assumptions (e.g. monoenergetic radiation, no scatter) which when included in the treatment above invalidate the general conclusions reached - see Figure 7.3. Nevertheless, logarithmic subtraction is widely applied in clinical DSA.
:Note that substantial compression of the gray scale results following direct logarithmic transformation and that multiplication of the transformed pixel values by a scaling factor is generally used to re-establish the gray scale.
